She saw Lila in profile and recognized the discipline of not looking at the person who mattered and the skill of appearing to be the one who could answer if a person insisted on making her day worse. When she had watched long enough to satisfy the part of her that enjoyed testing the polish on the city and finding where it had not taken, she went downstairs and stood, smaller than she preferred to be, beside Tomas and said without ornament that he was causing work. He told her he had been hired to cause work and she almost laughed because she preferred impertinence when it was dressed properly and did not come with slogans. She asked him whether he intended to continue being an audience member with excellent taste or whether he meant to write a program, and he said he was trying to teach people how to clap without waiting for a cue. They stood a long minute together, two people who distrusted the romance of eye contact, and she said, in a voice in which she did her most generous lying, that if he paired again, temporarily, she could make a part of this official enough that he would not have to practice his sneaking so often. He told her he would pair if the Book learned to whisper he rather than it when speaking about citizens, and she said he was asking for a hug and a dictionary from a machine that had been fed on recipes for obedience, and he said that meant he was asking the right person.

The Keepers moved with the confidence of people who believed that angles loved them and cameras would always choose their good side, and for a minute the lobby considered a role reversal and decided against it because the children were watching and people had worn their good coats to see a thing that was not a scuffle. Lila found the one with his jaw already squared for regret and leaned into his gravity and said there were three of him in the room even if he did not see the other two, and if he wanted to go home later without discovering a bruise shaped like a country he had never visited, he would move left now and then right later and he would think of his mother on a bench somewhere knitting a scarf for a winter that would not come. He moved because good soldiers recognize orders when they do not arrive in the proper packaging, and because his shoes had always regretted friction. Ezra’s decoy yawned on schedule, and three men with high collars yawned back involuntarily, and in that small involuntary exchange a plan deflated enough to no longer be dangerous.

At six when the light makes every story prettier than the truth by half a step, Anaïs took a breath she had been saving since the first rumor and told a group of women who had never met that yes, the ball had been moved, and no, the city was not going to ignite because people stood very close to something old and remembered their own bodies. She said, and she allowed herself the indulgence of the word because she had earned it, that care was not piety, and that respect was not obedience, and that a crack in a ball and in a story could serve as measuring tools rather than as excuses. Tomas lifted a child to see and felt for a moment the ghost of the guard’s old chiding and felt then also his father’s hands, not lifting the child but teaching him the posture of lifting, which is different. He caught a woman’s eye across the case and knew because of the way she smiled that for the rest of her week she would be slightly kinder to her own lungs.

Outside, a woman with a megaphone tried a phrase that would have got a person arrested last year and received instead a glare that said people were busy with something that required more tenderness than yelling. Two boys kicked a sock-ball very gently between their shoes as if teaching themselves the anatomy of compliments, and a Keepers’ van purred like a cat waiting to be told it had been good. Lila stood with her hands in her pockets and reminded herself that pockets are for weapons and secrets and one of those is illegal and the other is not, and then reminded herself that the legality of secrets had been changed overnight before by women with smiles like lids on boiling pots. She saw Tomas begin to step toward the wrong door, and she lifted her chin a fraction to remind him that this building had three exits and the one he was choosing would deliver him into hands that had washed themselves recently in anticipation.

He ducked left into the corridor that smelled of lemon because no one had learned yet that lemon made people think of childhood, and he passed the service room where he had briefly become an unperson and felt the temptation to go in and do it again just to see if it felt different now that he had admitted to himself that he liked breathing without accompaniment. He put an orange on the base of the case because it pleased him to put something bright and mortal near something old and adored, and because he liked the notion that the cameras would not know where to file the gesture and perhaps the City would enjoy, for once, a moment for which there was no approved caption. On the street a man with a hat asked him for a sheet of his pamphlet and offered a stamp in return, and Tomas took the stamp because stamps make you feel like there are still systems that can be gamed elegantly without spilling blood. He walked to the square where the pigeons have no respect and the children throw corn and the old men argue about line calls in matches they did not attend, and he listened to the air settle now that the day had gotten its way with them.

At home, his mother put the soup on the table and told him his aunt had commented on the crack as if it were a scratch on a new car, and he said his aunt had earned the right to be precise and ungenerous in her metaphors. They played cards and she cheated before he got the chance, which she did to signal that she had not completed her transformation into a saint and would prefer if he did not force it upon her with his earnestness. She asked what he planned to call the thing he was building and he said he did not intend to name it at all because names behave like ropes and he needed something more like water, and she rolled her eyes and told him if he started talking like a priest she would make him scrub the baseboards until he remembered where the broom lived.

By midnight the Mayor’s people were trial-ballooning an ordinance that would please the frightened and irritate the self-possessed, a policy with a long aspirational title that could be shortened to something as crude as a bruise if someone wanted to chant against it. They called it an act and packed into it smaller acts, and one of them would give the Book the authority to suggest and then insist on certain routes through the city for citizens whose rings read as agitated. Mira read the draft and wrote in the margin, quietly, that agitated was a category best left to water and children, and she balanced her pin on the edge of her desk as if she might allow it to fall and then did not. She imagined a future in which she permitted Tomas his project and admired its ferocity from a distance while clipping it when it brushed against power, and she imagined a different future where she cut it now and bore the headlines later, and she did the math with a calm that made her junior staff nervous because they preferred their cruelty to come with motion.

The next morning Tomas stood at the edge of a court that had not been painted in two summers and told whoever walked by that this was not a meeting, because meetings have chairs and minutes and these were feet and seconds. He said it again and again until it became part of the air and did not require his mouth, and people arrived with oranges because news travels fastest when it arrives as a joke. They put the oranges at the corners, not because it meant anything mystical but because it translated a circle into a square you could see from a window. He held up the sheet with the dotted lines and explained the drill and asked for someone who knew how to bark at timing without making enemies, and a woman with a voice that had frightened her into a good job volunteered to be heard. They ran the pattern until people felt both smarter and more foolish than they had an hour before, and when a man threw too hard and apologized without prompting, Tomas felt something like the Book’s pulse in his old index finger and told himself it was simply blood remembering it had circuits of its own.

They did it again at dusk under a bridge because bridges are where you go to keep faith and because the weather had decided to be magnanimous in a way that made everyone suspicious. Ezra arrived with grease on his sleeve and a grin that meant he had convinced someone to do something dignified, and he brought three boys who had learned to sprint between cars and not die, and he brought the locksmith who refused to admit he had come to watch and insisted he was there to judge posture. Lila stood with her back to a pillar and called advice that sounded like scolding and scolded in a tone that felt like care, and when someone asked her what they were training for she said that the person who demands a plan before they pick up their feet will always be late. A girl whose braid would not hold said she did not want to be chosen last by captains anymore even in games that were not real, and Tomas told her that no captain worth anything would choose last, and she rolled her eyes and told him he was very good at prettifying disappointment.

A boy brought a copy of the pamphlet to his grandmother and she read it aloud in a courtyard where the laundry trapped the sun, and two men who had not spoken in a decade agreed on one sentence and allowed themselves the luxury of pretending that was a reconciliation. In an office where the carpet felt like a lie, a woman penciled a schedule for officers to stand in unattractive weather at the edges of courts and pretended she was planning for safety and not for spectacle, and then she put down her pencil and walked outside and took her jacket off and tried the drill in high heels and did not fall, which taught her something she did not intend to learn. In the Hall, beneath the bronze, Anaïs replaced flowers that had wilted with a dish of olives because she had decided the building needed salt, and she found the orange at the base of the case and held it to her face and smelled the day someone took a risk and did not go to jail for it, and she put the orange in her bag because the building was not going to eat it and she liked a fruit with a use.

By the weekend the city had decided that if the crack was going to be with them it might as well be given a chair at the table, and there were shirts that made it into a joke and then into a prayer and then back into a joke again, which is the proper route for symbols if you do not want them to grow too tall. The ordinance changed its angle twice and shed two unsettling verbs and acquired one new noun, and Mira adjusted her jaw like a woman choosing a necklace that says something without getting her robbed. The Book learned to list Tomas as an address when people searched for directions to a thing that did not have one, and it blinked and hummed and then let the error go because the algorithm had been taught, one time in a flood, to step aside when human traffic needed the lane. Tomas walked to his mother’s on Sunday with a bag of soup and two oranges and a deck of cards, and he knocked three-twos and a pause because superstition had joined his growing toolbox and was proving heavier than expected.

She made fun of his hair and then touched his face in the doorway because those actions share an origin, and she asked him how long he planned to be young enough to get away with momentum as a strategy. He told her he was tired, not in a way that complained but in a way that admitted he had begun to understand he would have to be, and she poured him soup and told him to eat it before it cooled into philosophy. They played, and she cheated again, and he caught her this time and she was pleased because being caught means you were seen, and she told him there would come a week when he would regret asking the city to behave like a person and not a machine and that she would be there to accept his apology when his feelings were bruised. He told her there would come a week when he would be grateful he had asked at all, and that he would bring her oranges then too, and she waved a hand and asked him to go to the market with her because the woman at the fish stall needed to be told her sign was misspelled and would not accept the correction from anyone who did not look like a person’s son.

On the way back from the market a van crept down the street like a thought someone did not want to say and then did, and Lila stepped from a doorway like a woman changing her mind about quitting a job and put her shoulder into the world just enough to make space. She did not look at Tomas because the role required indifference, and she told the driver she had reports of a sinkhole ahead and a very old woman who wanted to exorcise it and that the van would be better off avoiding both religion and unplanned geology for an hour. The driver recognized the tone that saves you paperwork later and turned, muttering the way men do when they suspect they are being cared for and do not know what to do with the kindness. Tomas stood with his mother’s bag of fish in his hands and felt, for the first time without flinching, the outline of an army he might be capable of assembling, not an army of uniforms and commands but of benches and drills and refusals at precisely the right decibel. He thought of Mira and of the pin and of the way her mind had traced his absence like a calligrapher unwillingly admiring a rival’s hand, and he thought of Anaïs and the olives, and he thought of Ezra’s scar and the locksmith’s resignation, and he thought of his sister’s laugh over a train bell, and he thought that if respect were a resource, they had been treating it like a statue when it wanted to be a rope.

That night, he took the pamphlet and wrote on the back with a pen that leaked sometimes and made his fingers look like he had been handling blueberries. He wrote down names paired with places, not to command them to be there but to remind himself where kindness had agreed to be bold: laundry, bridge, market, bench, gym, hall, classroom, stoop. He saw on the paper the beginnings of a net not made of metrics but of habits, and he understood with the slow solemnity of a revelation that the Book had never been a book to begin with, merely a loud room where people had been told to whisper into a single microphone. He did not know whether he was making a better room or simply another microphone, and he closed his eyes on that tremor because doubt is the seasoning that keeps you from poisoning anyone by accident. In another building, a law hardened by two signatures and a press release, and in the morning a field somewhere would be painted over with a brighter white and the edges would look crisper and less forgiving, and the children would trip on them and learn again the geometry of running and stopping and choosing which is harder.The evening Mira promised arrived wearing good manners like gloves, and the city accepted them because it likes to be courted in public before it is told what to do. All day the procurement teams called the candles lights and arranged them in boxes that felt like shipping kindness, and the feeds softened their fonts and practiced a tone that suggested grief had learned posture. The ordinance with the aspirational name had shed two of its more officious verbs after committee and acquired a clause about flexibility at the discretion of trained officers, which worried the people who worried, and relieved the people who preferred to be told these things were under control. On the trains, hands that did not usually carry anything carried white paper bags with strings of wax peeking like shy ideas, and the Book trailered beneath its banners a request for calm in the timbre of a mother at the end of a long day.

Tomas did not dress differently because costume would have felt like a lie even if he was arriving at a performance. He folded fifty sheets into his pocket with the same embarrassment a man feels carrying flowers for himself, and he put two oranges in his coat because superstition had become a form of inventory. He met Ezra at the edge of a square that cleaned itself on Saturdays and now shone like a conscience, and they stood watching the city arrange itself into versions of itself, the way you watch a crowd compose a photograph that will become the reference point for a year. The locksmith came in wool despite the warmth and positioned himself near a tree in case any metal decided to misbehave in his presence, and he looked as if he might scold a hinge for squeaking too publicly. Lila did not arrive so much as never leave; she had been at the edges of it all day, a kneecap in the city’s stride, deciding when to apply pressure.

Mira took the stage when the hour made silhouettes flattering, and she did not bring the Mayor up with her because she understood ratios. She wore white because her hair had taught her the uses of monochrome, and she spoke briefly because the city had sat through enough long speeches to use the carpet as a mirror. She talked about rooms and light and history that refuses to be a flat painting, and she did not say ball because the word sounded like play, but she gestured in a way that made every camera line up the crack with her profile. She asked for nothing and suggested a posture, and then she stepped back and let a choir of schoolchildren sing not a hymn but a round about names, the sort of song that had traveled classrooms for two generations without flags being attached to it, and that felt like safety to people who were out of practice.

Anaïs stood in the Hall with her hands lightly folded, not prayer but readiness, and she looked at the glass with an expression you reserve for friends you have already forgiven for something they have not yet admitted. The guards were bored and trying to hide it, which is a species of courage no one applauds. The case breathed in the manner of expensive things, which is to say only when you get too close. The ball sat cheaply and grandly inside its square like a saint who will never be canonized officially because enough grandmothers decided it was done. People came in two at a time and then three and then in clusters that moved with the choreography of decency rather than that of instruction, and Anaïs watched a woman in a suit put her hand on her husband’s sleeve not to control him but to adjust his angle toward the scuff that meant the story had stopped being an advertisement.

The plan for the evening from the side that does not write speeches was a circle, nothing more sophisticated than a diagram turned into motion. Ezra had drawn it in chalk that would not show on the stone and then had the sense to step back and let the crowd erase it with their feet. He started the first pass near the second fountain, where a statue pretended not to notice pigeons, and Tomas took up the other end by the bronze woman who holds a whistle like a sceptre. They did not bark orders; they asked questions that had been rehearsed in basements and on benches. If a person wanted to move to the pillar, they pointed to the person behind them and said, Your turn. If a person wanted to stand still, they opened their hand and let someone else pass through. It was small and infuriatingly gentle, the sort of revolution that leaves your shoelaces tied and your eyes a little wet because someone did not jostle you when you expected it and had prepared a defense for the jostle.

At first the Book misfiled what it saw as milling because its categories are good at distinguishing bodies but not at recognizing grace, and that gave them three minutes to be beautiful without commentary. When the Keepers’ van hummed closer and found the nearest sensible place to be, which was slightly in the way, Lila stood at the edge of the circle and adjusted it by a degree and a sentence until the people moving were the ones who were impatient and the ones standing still were the ones who wanted to feel useful. Order arrived disguised as courtesy and took a breath no one heard. The van settled into the chug of an animal that has learned to wait. The junior inside, jaw squared for regrets he hoped to earn, watched the movement and wrote it off as the sort of thing citizens invent when asked to entertain themselves.

The provocation, when it arrived, came from the usual place: a man who believed damage is a kind of confession and who mistrusted an evening without an opportunity to be more important than his neighbors. He did not throw a flare at the Hall because Lila would have broken his wrist before his shoulder decided, and because even that kind of foolishness had learned to be self-protective. He tried instead to spray a slogan on the plinth of the bronze ball, a sentence that had been the title of an article last week and an epithet the week before, and he shook the can in a way that made the little ball inside clatter like a bell. The circle near him tightened and then loosened, a strange pulse that made space for Lila’s hand without making its hunger obvious, and in that pause a boy of nine stepped in and put his palm flat on the stone where the paint would have landed, and the man did not know how to proceed because his target had turned into a child’s hand. Lila took the can at the wrist and removed it with the sort of efficiency that graduates you into gentleness, and she passed it to a grandmother who had appeared from somewhere with a bag and the bag took the can as if it were a cucumber. The boy looked at his hand as if it had been held up by gravity, and then he went back to kicking his sock-ball at his sister, and the city allowed itself the surprise of a moment that did not escalate.

Mira watched from the stage and did not use her microphone because this was not hers to speak over, and she filed away the image of the grandmother with the cucumber-bag, because if she would be using this night later she would prefer the metaphor kept its realism. When the choir finished singing the names round, she addressed them as if she had noticed they had done something difficult well, which is the sort of compliment that keeps children from having to become officers later to feel valuable. She said, and she meant it in the way she allowed herself to mean things without flinching, that light was useful only if it was not weaponized, and she let the word crack appear on her tongue only once, and she pointed at it on the feed because she was not an idiot and because claiming a symbol early is how you protect it from people who have leisure to ruin it systematically.

The vigil had that soft ending that crowds invent when they are determined not to be orchestrated, and candles were pinched neatly instead of crushed like vanguards under a heel, and the square exhaled into streets that learned their lessons for the hour and then reverted to habit because cities are merciful to their own defects. Tomas felt the cutter’s tug of adrenaline let go and in its absence the ache of having been good, a low hum in the bones that had nothing to do with righteousness and everything to do with not standing on the outside of his day. Ezra clapped him on the shoulder with a friend’s brutality and told him that at least he had not been poetic in public, which deserved a pin, and the locksmith cited three doors that had enjoyed being opened without being impressed by themselves and suggested it could become standard practice if the city learned to trust its own wrists.

The ordinance became a pamphlet overnight, the way laws do when the nervous need to see them in their kitchens to believe in them, and Tomas found one tumbling in the gutter and read it while walking because that was how it wanted to be consumed. The guided routes had been softened into suggestions, with a collapsible list of “conditions of agitation” that would stand in court like a curtain does in a draft, proving only that a room is not entirely sealed. The clause about officer discretion had been italicized, which is the font you use when you want to whisper and be obeyed, and the diagrams were pretty because pretty sells fear to people who think they had their fill of it last year. He folded it into a square with the confidence of a boy who had learned to make paper into a ball and bounced it twice off a wall to hear if the sound had changed. It had not.

They raided the locksmith the next morning the way men who have been told to prove their relevance raid a bakery they suspect of selling wheat without stamps. It was polite and thorough to the degree that signals training and resentment; they asked where he had gotten the copper for the imitation rings and lectured him about fashioning lies, and he listened with the calm of someone who had survived three currencies and one winter when everyone learned how to reinforce windows with dignity. He lifted the late-model chips into the teapot by the register as if making tea and set down in their place a row of antique skeleton keys, an apology in metallurgy. When they left, he locked his door twice for the first time in a year and sent a boy with a very good sense of direction to tell Tomas, not because his shop was in danger but because someone needed to be reminded that the city had ears and no obligation to be kind when it got curious.

Mira summoned Tomas to her office without doing him the discourtesy of pretending it was a coincidence, and he went in with the exact caution of a man carrying something he could not ask the metal detector to ignore. The building breathed him and did not find the old pulse because the imitation ring was too polite to draw attention to itself, and that was an omen he would misinterpret later. Inside, the office looked like a photograph of a room that has seen a better argument, and Mira did him the honor of not pointing to a chair as if she were a hostess. She told him, still standing because some concessions need to be staged quite carefully, that she had no interest in arresting him as long as his next act did not humiliate her in front of people who were already predisposed to enjoy her humiliation. He told her he lacked the imagination to stage a humiliation sufficiently refined to satisfy her critics, which was a compliment if you understood the nerve required to say it.

She made him an offer that did not insult either of them so much as it tickled their old loyalties. He could pair again in a fashion that was half-ceremonial, join a pilot for teaching crowd management that avoided the word control, allow his pamphlet to be printed on better paper with a seal peeking out of the corner like a chaperone, and in exchange he would be given a radius inside of which no one would test his sincerity with handcuffs. For a minute he saw the elegance of it the way architects admire an arch, and then he saw the way it would turn his movement into an accessory, and he told her that he could bring his drills and his citrus to the city’s stages if she promised to let failure be public and not to call it treason when a circle broke. She smiled in a way that taught him something about her he would not be able to use later, and she said she could promise it until Friday.

Lila watched the building adapt to having him inside it again, as if their conversation had fetched him back into the visible spectrum. She took the file her supervisor handed her with the air of a woman accepting the weather and read inside it a set of cautions that amount to affection when your employer is a city. Observe without discouraging, intervene without interrupting, permit the optics of kindness and suppress the optics of drift. She allowed herself the long private exhalation of a person who knows their job is to stand between a creative force and a law and keep both of them from embarrassing themselves, and she went downstairs and bought a packet of sunflower seeds because a courtyard nearby liked to be littered with something you could pretend was an innocent habit.

The schools adopted the part of the ordinance that makes the Book proud even when it is sad: the ask for rings to be worn visible for safety, the suggestion of routes, the language about supervision that makes teachers revolt briefly in stairwells and then go back to inventing workarounds. His sister called and emptied the sound of a bell into his ear by holding the phone near the hallway during change of class, and she laughed under her breath when she told him that eight girls in her second class had threaded baker’s twine through their rings and made them into pendants and then tucked them inside their shirts, and that when the keeps-everything-straight administrator asked why, they said modesty and were not contradicted. He went to stand outside her school at dismissal, not to commit spectacle but to measure the city’s evenness, and he saw the routes push and pause and adjust with the softness that will keep a child from turning into a clerk when she grows. He bought oranges and put them at two corners, not as charms but as promises, and the mothers smiled at him and allowed him to exist because he was holding fruit and not a megaphone.

In the Hall, the label Anaïs had written in pencil survived the first wave of committees simply because no one had the stamina to object to a sentence that did not lean its weight on anyone, and under it the ball sat with a crack showing like an ankle, which in this city has always made people braver than they intended to be. She allowed a reporter to ask a polite question and she answered it with discourtesy disguised as a story about paint that did not match, and the reporter snuck her words onto a feed with a caption that made it sound as if the news had come up with the anecdote itself, and she went home tired and did not mind that the exhaustion had a tone she had missed. She bought two oranges on the way because she had begun to understand the currency they represented, and when she reached her stoop a girl with a braid asked if she could smell them, and Anaïs handed one over and let the girl breathe it as if it were a book.

The city learned the shape of Tomas’s refusal like a new piece of furniture in a familiar room, stubbed into it twice, and then rearranged itself to avoid bruising the same shin again. He discovered the limits of his ring’s courtesy when he tried to collect his pay from an account that had been made conditional on acknowledgment of a tool he had taught himself to live without, and he stood in the bank with his palms open and told the young woman behind the glass that he could not offer recognition and that he had brought the paper of his pay in a file he could show her, and she did the math of decency and let the transaction proceed because sometimes discretion is just a clerk choosing not to ask a question. He slept one night in the gym because his building’s lock decided to be proud and then ashamed and then obstinate, and the sound of Ezra’s snore was both an insult and a benediction, and in the morning he washed his face in a sink that had been taught humility by years of chalk and sweat, and he felt human enough to continue.

They printed more sheets and did not call them anything, and the map of places grew into a list that lived on paper and in elbows: the laundry that would store your bag if you promised to wash two loads for strangers on Tuesdays; the bridge where children would be taught a pattern and then insist on teaching it to their uncles; the market where oranges were cheaper on Wednesdays for people who wore their imitation rings inward or not at all; the bench where old men would adopt two seats and make anyone who sat between them answer a question about whether respect was more like salt or like a broom. The Book tried briefly to categorize oranges as suspicious and then, when that misfire began to go badly on the feeds, surrendered and filed them as produce again, which is part of what keeps people sane in systems older than they are.

Mira visited her tailor after the evening because it calms the mind to have an old woman accuse you of wanting shoulders too broad for your actual guilt, and she let herself be pinned and prodded and teased into considering the fabric of a season in which she would have to move a fraction more like a penitent and a fraction less like a monarch. She instructed two Keepers to stand on a corner she knew would become important because respect had gone and gotten itself an address, and she made sure their orders included an admonition about their expressions because she did not want photographs of a scowl near a child learning to stand in a circle. She wrote one sentence in her own hand at the bottom of a memo and it said: This city thinks with its feet when you let it, and she put it in a folder that did not belong to any of her staff because she was sentimental in ways only she would notice.

On a Monday that refused to be better than it had to be, Lila found a notice in her box that might as well have been a summons, and it was written not in legal grammar but in the smaller cruelties of an institution that has decided to refine your purpose. She was to monitor the phenomenon in the squares and the courts and provide regular guidance, which looked like expertise until you read the line about escalation thresholds and understood that her job was not to bless a practice but to stand near it with scissors. She took the notice and used its clean edge to slice a dangling thread from her sleeve, and she told herself that this is what a decent bureaucrat does when asked to scratch at a callus: you tend to the finger with one hand and keep the other out of the socket. She met Tomas at a corner crowded with sunlight and told him that if he intended to make something permanent he should plan to watch it be stolen, and he told her that he had no intention of calling permanence anything but courteous stubbornness until they survived a winter.

The second crackdown arrived not as boots but as questions, because someone had decided to teach the public to ask for credentials again like a habit you put down for a season and have to be shown where it goes on the table. Men who were unused to being asked to carry proof of their names rediscovered indignation like an heirloom and polished it in cafés until the waiters got tired and asked them to drink or leave. Women who had long since learned the physics of being weighed by glances decided to provide papers proactively and then look at the faces of the readers until some of those faces broke into something human. Tomas had nothing to show and could show it with a clean conscience, and he learned a new way to keep his hands, palms out, fingers splayed, not surrender and not threat but a posture you want to invent if you have no desire to be dragged into a room without windows.

His mother learned to carry oranges in her bag as if they were a prescription, and she began slicing them on her stoop and passing segments to any child who would take one without asking for a better story than thirst, and she told her sister that she did not intend to be anyone’s symbol and that the day would come when her son would be punished for letting her become one. She withheld her game of cards one Sunday because punishment needs practice, and she watched his face learn that love and discipline are not two teams in a stadium but two halves of a rule. He went away after soup with the particular heaviness that announces a necessary humility and worked it out on a kitchen wall until someone banged with a broom, and he apologized to a ceiling and meant it.

The flood wandered back into the city’s memory as summer drew itself up and made the river impatient, and in that collective shiver Tomas found a grammar he could use without calculation. He began to talk about drills as if he were asking someone to move a couch, and he found that when he framed respect as the art of not dropping something heavy on your neighbor’s foot most people wanted to learn. He took to carrying a sketchbook like a tourist and drew diagrams of square corners and arcs of movement and the posture of a person braced to lift, and when people asked him if he was an artist he said no, which made them generous, and when they asked if he was a soldier he smiled and did not answer, which made them careful. He went to a hardware store and bought twelve hex keys and handed them out one at a time to people who had fathers or mothers who had taught them not to turn in a hurry, and he told each of them to fix one small thing in the city and then not to talk about it until someone else noticed.

On a day Mira had marked for meetings and instead filled with silence and tea because exhaustion had come to collect its bill, the Mayor made a joke about oranges and received laughter that taught her it was not yet hers to make, and in the Hall a child brought a lemon and put it next to the case because her mother had run out of the other fruit, and Anaïs did not move it because substitution is a form of faith. Ezra lost a game underground and celebrated it because losing had become rare courtesy, and the locksmith taught a girl to seat a pin so gently that the lock sighed and then agreed, and Lila wrote three words on her palm that would not transfer to other surfaces no matter how much she wanted them to: patience beats pride. Tomas sat on a bench and wrote that he would rename nothing and that names are a way to close a hand, and he looked at his own hands and thought for a second that two oranges were quite a lot to ask of a person, and then the boy with the scar came by and stole one and peeled it and handed him a segment without explaining why we share, and he accepted, which is a language too.The river did its old trick of pretending to be asleep and then opening its eyes all at once. It came up with the specific indifference of water that remembers a route no one taught it, creeping first into alleys that had been repaved since the last time and did not think of themselves as vulnerable, then into the undersides of bridges where pigeons had enjoyed sovereignty, and then into basements like a guest who declines the good chair and sits on the stairs instead. The weather menaced in courteous phrases because the Book had taught even clouds to consider the optics, and the alerts arrived like toasts at a wedding wherein everyone was trying not to mention a cousin who always ruined the cake. People said it like gossip because that is how you make fear absorbable: up a finger’s width on the south gauge, a palm on the east, the Old Quarter flirting with the third step already, better bring in the rugs.

Lila heard it first as a change in the footfalls on her stairwell. The building had a particular composure when it rained and another when it flooded, and this morning it had chosen the latter, filling with the quick polite steps of people determined to be on the useful side of necessity. She checked the routes the Book suggested and watched three little animated flows try to use the same narrowing of street by the bronze woman with the whistle, and she swore under her breath not at the flood but at the diagram. The revised ordinance had already imagined this—guided routes for agitation, suggested paths for order—and it did the wrong thing beautifully now, channeling everyone toward a choke point so photogenic it felt cruel. She called it in to Mira and said, not in code because sometimes clarity is the kindness you offer a superior, that if they did not break their own rails for an hour they would be explaining to grandmothers why high heels make poor paddles.

Mira was at her desk with a damp pin on her lapel and a jug of coffee that had been attempting to look authoritative. She had lived through three floods and a coup that had only been named that after it failed, and she understood the art of arresting a reflex. She walked to the window and watched the river try on a new bank like a dress it might keep, and she told Lila calmly to walk the routes closed by remembering which doors the city liked to leave ajar. She called three Keepers and told them their discretion was now policy. She called the Mayor and told her not to wear boots on camera because the boots would make apologies look like vanity. She sent a note to the Book in the only language it always processed before any other—maintenance—and requested, on behalf of Civic Flow, an emergency widening of the deletion throttle for rerouting notices, because now was not the time for arguments with a system about dignity. She wrote in her own hand at the bottom of the memo: Let the feet choose.

Tomas woke to the city making the sound it makes when it is thinking about drowning. He put one orange in his pocket and then another because superstition is not something you fight on a day that asks for obedience to older gods. He slid the imitation ring to the middle joint of his finger and willed it to behave, then put his ear to the window because the water speaks to people with no microphones if you let it. It said the simplest thing a river ever says, which is hurry wisely. He went out and found Ezra already on the steps with a coil of rope that seemed tired of living in a bag and eager to be a line between two obligations, and they did not argue because floods do not enjoy debate. They went to the bridge first, where a cluster of people had gathered to be clever and take pictures, and Ezra banged a rhythm on the railing that managed to be both festive and alarming, which is the form of punctuation a crowd will obey if it has just been given something worthwhile to do.

The drills had been a kindness when they were pretend; now they were a permission. Tomas put down his sheets and did not apologize for his own handwriting. He took chalk from a boy who looked proud of the theft and drew three arrows on the ground that would defy the Book’s purpler map, and then he moved until people’s eyes found his shoulders and used them as law. He did not bark, he asked in the tone of someone handing you something heavy that he does not want to drop on your foot. The circle was a corridor now, the dotted line a chain made of patience and rope. The market gave up its oranges because fruit prefers to be eaten but will substitute itself as a bright mark whenever the city is confused, and they laid the fruit on stairwells and at the head of a slope into the subway so people would know which direction the favor ran. Ezra took three boys and taught them how to lock a gate open without bending the metal’s feelings, and the locksmith appeared like a condemnation with a hand saw and a bag of apologies and began to talk to hinges the way you talk to the last stubborn relative at a wedding table.

The Book tried to follow and then tripped. Its routes looked clean on a screen but in the wet the corners changed their angles like cats crossing a room, and the rings began to stutter: agitated, relaxed, wet, unauthorized, wet. The emergency gates at the Hall blinked themselves into an ethical crisis; they had been taught to open for women and for emergency badges and for the official stanchions of a filmed tour, but not for the messy, uncoiffed flow of a city deciding in a hurry to be decent. Tomas reached the back door and presented the polite lie of his ring and got a refusal that tasted like tin, and before he could retry the old developer trick, Lila stepped from the lobby’s shadow and pressed the heel of her hand at the precise point where old wood flirts with pride. The door learned again the muscle memory of a good shove. It opened as if ashamed of being an obstacle. She did not look at him and he did not thank her, because the city had been designed to be grateful to itself in emergencies, and they both respected the architecture.

Inside, Anaïs had made her decision before she stood up. You move the labels first, not because they are more precious than the objects but because they are light and they remind you what language you planned to use when you were less afraid. She went through the gallery with her arms full of laminated sentences and set them high, and then she stood before the case and looked at the ball as if it might say do not fuss. She did not intend to be the curator who drowned protecting a sphere, but she also did not intend to present the city with a headline that suggested it had lost its nerve and its original sin in the same night. She turned down the Book’s eyes in the room because grief should not be asked to give good angles, and she called out to the boys with the rope in a voice that no one heard as pleading because age had given it a condescending clarity. They sandbagged the door that liked to fail in warm weather. She told a girl in a jacket to stand by the photograph of the goal and explain to anyone who would listen why the paint had mismatched on the railings in the old stadium, because floods require distractions as much as they require bags of dirt.

The first wave reached the hall like a guest who had memorized the address properly and wished to leave a gift. It put two inches on the floor in the service corridor and then reconsidered entering the lobby because the angles were wrong and the crowd’s posture was discouraging of insult. A boy whose boots had been made for puddles and policy sloshed in and found a bucket and was instantly important in the way nine-year-olds are when a room is misbehaving. The case fogged; the crack became a white line as unapologetic as chalk. Someone took a picture because you cannot help it; everyone else turned to sand with their hands. Lila took two Keepers in their crisp uniforms by their elbows and smiled at them with such warmth that it took them four minutes to realize they were stacking bags at a pace she had not permitted herself in a year. Ezra’s rope decided it would be a chain barrier and then thought better of its vocation and became a dragline for the nearest drain. The locksmith found a grate that had lost its screws to enthusiasm two administrations earlier and put it back in line with a hex and a murmur.

Across the river, guided routes on screens in buses updated themselves with the desperate confidence of a person who carries a map and refuses to ask a child for directions. Congestion happened where congestion always happens when people mistake pretty lines for streets, and a necessary panic began to practice its vowels. Mira went to the rotunda with its sickly acoustics and told a roomful of microphones that the city had been asked to solve puzzles before and had solved them with its knees as often as with its chin. She named, without naming, the people calling the drills at the corners and the boys who had learned how to get a gate to open for a kid and a dog at the same time, and when a Keeper’s supervisor asked on a very live channel whether this was an endorsement of unauthorized civil practice, she said calmly that it was a suspension of enforcement and an endorsement of survival. The Mayor arrived in boots that were not a joke and stood behind her as if she had learned in a single hour the etiquette of second chairs. Someone in the corner counted this as a victory and put it in a file. Mira watched them and decided to follow up later and make certain it did not become a performance.

Tomas learned a thing that day about design. A circle that had been a drill could be turned into a wheel that pulled a person out of a street when a car decided it wanted to be a boat. Four people in a square could make a ladder if you were generous with your shoulders. If you asked an old woman to hold a rope and told her what it was attached to, she would hold it until her hands blistered and then find someone with younger skin to take over without false ceremony. The oranges that had been wayfinding became floats for a minute and then signals bobbing at the mouths of alleys, a constellation that taught the aerial cameras humility because they could not see the pattern clearly enough to name it. He catalogued silently which corners held because the children already knew where the water would go, and which failed because someone had once rewritten a curb in a report and forgotten to tell the curb.

In the middle of the hurry there were the odd small graces. A woman who had always been careful with her voice found herself shouting orders to two men and liked the sound sufficiently to look embarrassed later in private. A Keeper who had been trained to make his presence an argument discovered that if he took off his hat children did what he asked faster. A boy whose father had told him never to be first at anything for fear of mistakes moved first anyway because a cat needed help getting out of a basement window and he recognized, without learning it, that there are rules and there are cats. A man in a wool coat who had never reached into a stranger’s bag without asking took the oranges out because the bag would float better lightened and for once didn’t ask to be forgiven.

They lost some things and pretended not to weep. Carpets went the way of all rugs in cities that have opinions about rivers. A school’s collection of outdated atlases became pulp in a hallway that for a week will smell like regret. A photograph in a frame on a stoop of a man who had not come home from a younger flood went soft, and his daughter picked up the wet paper and flattened it under the glass again because it felt more faithful to suppose that the man’s face had simply learned to live in water. The Hall kept the ball, and if that sentence felt proud to Anaïs as she thought it, she forgave herself because the cases are not meant to be funerals.

By afternoon the river found its ceiling in the neighborhood where the brick remembers better than the concrete. The city exhaled in increments because it had learned not to be greedy with relief. Lila stood with her hands on her hips and allowed herself to notice the pain that had taken up lodging under her rib when the sirens started, then put her hands down because posture becomes a habit and she did not want to teach a new generation of girls to hold themselves in readiness for too long. The Keepers who had been sent to police postures found themselves stacking crates and repeating jokes they hoped would convert panic into rhythm. The van that had waited earlier for an excuse now idled like an old cat, clean and without purpose. The ordinance, in a small miracle of bureaucratic grace that she would later pretend she had planned, read to her in a new draft as If the water exceeds the curb by more than three inches the routes are suggestions and the officers are citizens until the second bell.

Mira gave away credit the way expensive women give away compliments—measured, sparkling, clearly expensive—and that is why it worked. She mentioned the boys with the ropes by their first names on a feed that did not usually carry names unless there was a title attached. She mentioned the oranges without charming herself, which would have been fatal, and then noted the laundry that had kept bags safe and the gym that had let people sleep and the bridge where a girl had counted and kept count even when her own mother needed a hand. The Book stuttered in the way it does when you ask it to tell a story instead of to count, and then it learned. It began to file certain movements under a new tag—pattern: courtesy—and someone with a sense of humor in a room Tomas would never see named a category of behavior respect not because they believed it but because they wanted to be on the side of an argument that was beginning to look like funding.

At dusk, when the city has always looked best at forgiving, the water began to make a sound like a crowd after a concert, tired and pleased with itself and ready to eat. People picked up their shoes and then their judgments and carried them home. Anaïs sat in the office with the plant and the stool and washed her hands in a bowl because the taps had elected piety and refused to work. She did not pray at the ball, and she did not call anyone a hero, and she took the orange from the base of the case and cut it and ate it deliberately and thought, This city remembers best when the memory has a taste.

The morning after, the oranges caught in the railings looked like a row of small suns hung out to dry. Children walked to school with their socks damp and their mouths full of commentary because they had discovered the crowd would listen to them if they talked in declarative sentences about who needed to be lifted next time. The locksmith opened his shop despite the wet and hung on the door a sign that read in his precise hand: Keys for doors stuck by damp pride. He expected to be raided again and looked forward to arguing about adjectives. Ezra found his rope heavy with the silt of useful work and draped it over a radiator as if it were laundry, hummed a tune that might have been older than the game, and allowed himself the little private disgust a man still feels about crying in public even when the public is busy.

Tomas walked the path the Book said he should and then the one the water had, and then the one his feet wanted, and he offered help where help had learned to be asked for politely. He saw the places where their drills had fit exactly into the city and the places where they had not, and he wrote two lists because lists comfort men who have been entrusted with a feeling they did not ask to own. He went to his mother’s and unclogged the drain with a metal hanger and a patience that had not died with his father, and when she said nothing about the flood or the oranges or the boys saving cats, he understood that her silence was the only way she could give him back his peace without diminishing herself. She set down soup and told him she would not be wearing boots to any vigils, and he told her he would not be the person to ask her to.

Mira received three letters hand-delivered by couriers who had learned to roll their trousers to the knee and keep their socks dry. One was from the Mayor’s office and contained three compliments and a suggestion that next time the optics might be tidier; she placed it under her water glass and watched the ink run. One was from a club of women with long memories and longer knives, congratulating her on a decision their grandmothers had recommended in letters none of the current staff had ever bothered to read; she wrote them back and said, you can thank Anaïs instead and do it with olives. The third letter had no sender and only one sentence, which said: we will not embarrass you unless you make us lonely, and she put that one in a drawer with a birthday card and the membership pin from the time she had allowed herself to be in a club that wanted her.

Lila stood in a meeting where the woman with the face of a saint and the habit of a butcher attempted to turn the flood into a set of metrics. She listened quietly to the polite brutality of a chart and then put her hand up only once to say that the number of people who raised their hands to carry something heavy counts for more than the number of times a route was obeyed. She was told to put it in an email because the Book cannot change its mind without a noun to pin to a graph, and she smiled and did what she was told because sometimes obedience is a way of resting. After, she went to the bridge where the chalk had been replaced with a smear and considered the river like an enemy who might one day be a friend if you both ended up at the same table by chance. Tomas appeared with two oranges and a look that suggested exhaustion had decided to be handsome for once, and he handed her one and said nothing because they had earned the right to be quiet together for a minute.

The flood washed one secret into the open. A neighbor who had lived at the edge of the boys’ basement court had stood in his doorway and told Ezra’s wife that he remembered the old man with the red box and the patience of the slow twist. He had been there the night Tomás’s father had waded in too far to fix the power on a floodlight at the end of the street so that an ambulance could see the hole where a car had gone down. He had told him not to, and he had done it anyway, and the light had come on for three minutes and given a dozen people the exact amount of clarity they had required to cross a street in the right direction, and then the current had, as they say in official reports, rearranged him for good. Tomas listened and thought not of heroism but of torque, of that last slow turn that a person offers a thing that does not intend to yield and then does. He went home and took the little hex key he had begun to carry and put it on the windowsill where the sun would teach it patience.

After the flood there were the small meetings that are not meetings. A laundry agreed with a corner store that oranges would be cheaper on days when the river coughs. The gym posted hours that meant men could sleep there when their buildings had decided to pretend they were boats. A school practiced a drill that did not carry the scent of terror but did include mothers and three very impatient dogs. Anaïs started a ledger on paper that listed which local histories could be moved upstairs fastest by children and which required lifting with hands that had lifted a couch, and she wrote herself a small, stern note about not crying where cameras could find her. The locksmith taught a girl to rekey her own bedroom door because a girl should not have to ask, and when her mother looked dubious he said, gently, that being safe had always been the origin of manners. Lila ordered her unit to carry sunflower seeds and a spare rope, and the new boy laughed and then, to his credit, bought the seeds.

The Book learned a new trick so slowly it was almost touching. It started to send messages that were not commands to certain rings when a certain tag was crossed with a certain weather, and the message did not say obey or proceed. It said ask, and then, as if it could not help itself, it said: thank you. Tomas saw one on someone else’s screen over a shoulder on a bus and almost dropped his orange because there is nothing more dangerous in a city than a system that has decided to learn politeness. He pressed developer mode almost without intending to and saw, in the quiet hum of the maintenance logs, a line that said: Anomaly: pattern—courtesy—reduced fatalities at Bridge C by 17% (estimated). He closed it quickly because he did not want to develop the habit of looking for applause in other people’s code.

He took one day to be foolish and took his sister to the Hall, because you do not tempt memory too often if you do not want it to become an adversary. They stood before the case and she made fun of the pomp, and he made fun of her making fun, and Anaïs caught them and pretended to scold because scolding is how you welcome people who have done the work without asking for a ribbon. A child stared at the crack as if it were the first polite imperfection she had been taught to enjoy, and the boy with the scar stood farther back because some love is better at a distance. Lila came in at the back, not in uniform, and stood a minute with her hands open as if to show she was not on duty and then left because she had paperwork for once and paperwork, if done with decency, can be a form of prayer.

When the water finally retreated like a shy actress and left the city to sweep its own stage, Tomas went to the river with his red box, which was not his father’s but might as well have been for what it carried. He did not toss it in because drama is cheap when it is private. He opened it and took out a key and turned it in his fingers until his hand learned again the patience he would need for the next refusal. He thought of Mira with her white hair and her arithmetic and of her offer dressed up as policy, and he thought of saying yes to certain stages and no to certain microphones, and he thought of Anaïs making her list in pencil and of Ezra’s rope smelling like a basement and of the locksmith hiding chips in his teapot while teaching polite people to press their shoulders into doors with more confidence. He thought of his mother on the stoop handing segments of orange to any child who asked properly, and he thought, not for the first time, that respect might be not a statue or a scarf but a tool you passed down as if it were family.

The city looked, for a week after, like it had been dipped very quickly in a different mood and set to dry. People carried themselves with the careful exhaustion of a person who has set a room back to rights and is trying not to notice that one chair will now always wobble. The ordinance returned to its quieter clothing and behaved itself with the primness of a rule that has been forgiven, and its clause about officer discretion remained italicized and therefore dangerous. The drills took on the character of older customs, like sweeping a stoop or naming a baby after a piece of the weather that nearly killed you. Tomas stopped correcting people when they called what they were doing a game because he had decided to be done pretending that pleasure and survival are distant cousins.

On a Wednesday so ordinary it felt brave, Mira convened a meeting she did not name. Anaïs came and brought an empty folder, which is what curators do when they suspect they will be asked to carry something ugly home. Lila came and stood without leaning because leaning could be misinterpreted as weariness in minutes later. The locksmith arrived a full five minutes late on purpose and then apologized elegantly because he had not been invited formally; Ezra sat in the back with a rope on his lap because he liked to see people glance at it and adjust their opinions of what mattered. They talked about scars and whether the city should teach itself to celebrate them, and they talked about the Book and whether it would forgive being taught to whisper please, and they talked about ordinances and italics and what to do about the corner by the bronze woman where the water enjoys practicing cruelty. Mira told them what she could give them officially—three hours of authorized circles a week, one supervisor with a title they would not hate, a line in a budget that would always be too small—and what she could not: safety from curiosity, protection from envy, a guarantee that their oranges would always be read as kindness and never as code. They left with no paper that contained their names and yet with an understanding that had substance, which is increasingly rare in cities that admire signatures.

The night after, the boys played in the basement with a sock full of sand because the river had taught them the intoxicating difference between weight and mass, and they practiced throwing in a room that had just enough ceiling to punish arrogance. Tomas stood with his back to the wall, the sound of the ball against it an old liturgy in a new church, and let himself, in that unguarded quarter hour, be the boy his father had imagined he might become: someone who does the slow turning of necessary bolts with the precision that will not make headlines and the care that could keep a room from drowning. When he left, he locked the door with the new key, and he did not tell anyone he had left it under the third brick where the mortar cracks, because secrets are only useful if they are useful to more than one person, and the city was finally beginning to remember how to share.The week after the water stepped back as if it had remembered there were other cities to toy with, the oranges began to appear in windows the way candles had when people still believed vigil could stop a law. No one announced it and therefore no one could be accused of announcing it, which satisfied both the tender and the tired. A grocer who had lost three sacks of potatoes and a granddaughter to a good marriage put two fruits on his sill every evening before he set his tally stick on its hook; a woman in a dress she had ironed twice toward the hem and never toward the collar set one behind a pot of basil so it would be visible to anyone with a nose and a need; a barber hung a little net of them over his mirror and told a boy who stared that sometimes a city chooses a color because it wants to feel as if it has a flag that cannot be confiscated. The Book refused to make a banner of any of this, not out of malice but out of confusion, which is, in certain lights, a kind of mercy.

Tomas found himself walking slower in neighborhoods where fruit sat in windows, not because he had earned the right to take credit for any of it but because the sight of bright circles being allowed to be only themselves made his shoulders relax the way good music does when someone remembers to modulate at the right bar. He kept the imitation ring polite and his palms visible and discovered the rhythm of a man other people had begun to expect to be present when kindness needed choreography. It embarrassed him; it made his throat warm. He wrote it down as a problem in the back of his head: how to not become necessary in a way that makes other people lazy. He carried the red box a few times without opening it, just to remind his hands they had been trained to turn things that resisted that none of this was a permanent permission or a costume.

Mira watched oranges turn into punctuation and decided to let them keep their grammar for as long as the sentence stayed grammatical. The ordinance, which had never been intended to be poetry, acquired two subclauses in her hand that made the legal team sigh with relief because they looked like work and the public roll their eyes because they looked like permission disguised as homework. She had written them in the hour after the flood when her shoes were still wet and she had been inclined to humiliate her enemies and decided instead to make them complicit. She invited a certain set of women—the kind men in her position refer to as “difficult” when they are not listening—to her office without calling it a listening session because fastidiousness would have ruined the thing, and she let them talk without pretending to take notes. When one of them asked whether oranges would be considered contraband, Mira very nearly smiled and said that contraband used to mean salt, which should teach them humility. She passed out glasses of water that did not taste of pipes. She ignored the Mayor’s aide who kept asking whether there would be a photo and took the pin off her lapel for the second time in a month so it would stop reading as an oath.

It had been too long since anyone attempted to formalize what he was doing without insulting it. The first insult arrived as flattery: a brand that made shoes your feet would forgive approached him in the guise of a photographer with clean hair and better manners than sense and asked if he would like to star in a campaign about everyday courage, and he said no because he did not want to learn to see his face in windows he did not own. A second insult came as funding: a man with a smooth ring and a laugh he had practiced offered to underwrite printed sheets and a little office in a building that did not yet have rats and would therefore require rent on time every month. Tomas listened politely because his mother had taught him that charity is often just attention someone wants to record, and he declined with the kind of grace that would not earn him enemies now but would cost him later when the man needed, as such men always do, to be seen tearing down what they had failed to purchase. He took the insults as a sign of health. Insults only bother the living.

Anaïs Vel was summoned to a room with glass and subtraction and suffered the indignity of being told to sit by a man who had learned to be comfortable without shoes somewhere expensive. He told her, with the confidence of someone who could hire three replacement curators for the cost of the carpet, that the Hall had always thrived when its narrative had been clear and that the recent flirtations with ambiguity, while thrilling to certain donors, had confused the base. She saw three things at once: his vowels, which had not been taught to pronounce the names of the corners of the city; his cufflinks, which made her hands itch for pliers; and the little white at the edges of his nostrils that told her he had lifted something heavy recently and found it heavier than his body believed things to be. “We sell clarity because clarity pays for the electricity,” he said, and she said, in the voice she had used on sons and husbands and plumbers who wanted to be paid twice for the same accident, that the ball’s crack would stay visible because honesty keeps the lights on longer. He told her there would be a vote. She told him he had already lost it and he asked her to leave because politeness is a leash they hand you when they are about to pull. In the elevator she allowed herself a small wicked grin because she had always loved elevators for their little theatre of containment; in the reflection she looked every inch the old woman in a tapestry with a pair of scissors in her lap, and the thought cheered her enough to get her through the next meeting with a junior who wanted to call her “auntie” and did not.

In the basement gym the game grew a second skin. The drills that had been drills in public and survival in a flood became practice for something no one wanted to name because names tell on you, and yet people need to point at a thing to talk about it. Ezra called it the circuit because he liked the ugly industrial ring of the word, and everyone pretended to hate it. They began to trace the same pattern at different scales: five bodies and thirteen dots and a dotted line in chalk and then the same pattern across a square with oranges and then the same pattern inside a building where the cameras had been taught to love symmetry and therefore watched all the right wrong things. Tomas did not call it anything. He called the numbers. He sat down with a girl whose father had been a policeman before the Book, and he showed her that the moment you resist is often the moment you double the noise in the room, and she taught him that sometimes noise protects. They were inventing a form of math that might, in another family, have turned into a better version of war.

Lila began the week believing she could hold everything she was being asked to hold with one hand while the other made the gestures that persuaded people the state had never meant anyone harm. By Wednesday she had to use both hands, and she did not like the feeling not because it made her look tired but because it meant something in the system had decided to act like a toddler in a doorway, insisting everyone step over it rather than getting up and moving. A new directive had arrived with important italics, reminding her to file weekly reports on informal gatherings that might “constitute emergent paramilitary formations.” The list of indicators included circles larger than fifteen people, repetitions of a call-and-response not initiated by the authorities, and the presence of fruit used as wayfinding or admission tokens. She read it twice and took a photograph and then ate it because she knew someone who would search her bin a week from now and had decided not to give them the pleasure of finding it intact. When she met Tomas on her lunch break without calling it a meeting, she told him to start acting as if there were faces in every blank space, and he said he had been assuming that since childhood. She told him the word paramilitary had entered the room and he laughed, which is what a sane person does right up until someone knocks at their mother’s door with the other version of the word on a paper with teeth.

The locksmith received a formal notice alleging that he manufactured devices intended to deceive civic infrastructure and inviting him to attend a voluntary conversation at a place that had the audacity to be called Neutral House. He set the paper under a wobbly table leg and came to the basement that night with his bag of patient metal like a man going to a baptism. He told the room that if anyone wanted a ring that lied, they could have one only if they swore to treat it as a tool and not as a garment, and that if any of the boys in the back had been playing with jammers they had bought with pretend money from someone with a haircut that required attention, he would take them apart and make them read the diagrams aloud until they learned shame. One boy laughed and then, to his credit, shut up and listened. The locksmith made two more rings that hum without consent and watched Tomas not ask for one. He felt an unexpected affection for the not-asking and hid it behind a lecture about temperature and solder.

The Book, having learned to whisper please to a set of rings during a flood, attempted to generalize courtesy and embarrassed itself. For three days it sent small messages to citizens near benches where drills were happening, messages that read as if they had been written by a careful aunt: Do you need a space? Would you like us to recommend a safe path? We have noticed patterns of courtesy nearby. It did not occur to it that surveillance was easier to digest under panic and more offensive under leisure, and it learned the lesson the way machines learn anything worth keeping—through public humiliation followed by a change in the rules. Mira told the team to stop A/B testing kindness and go back to smoothing the edges of loud corners. A junior engineer, who had taught himself the maintenance taps during the flood and thought that meant something radical had happened inside him, wrote a memo suggesting the Book learn to ask the city what it wants before assuming the answer. The memo was not read aloud at any of the meetings. The junior took to visiting the bridge after work and counting oranges like stars.

Tomas’s sister, whose school had learned the art of being official and disobedient at the same time, found her pendants confiscated by a vice principal who had convinced herself that modesty was an act of aggression. The girls came to class the next day with rings tied to their shoelaces and looked the woman in the eye until she looked down and found herself smiling despite having intended to do the opposite. That afternoon their teacher took them out into the courtyard and showed them how to make circles with chalk that could be washed off quickly when someone came asking about property, and she told them to practice choosing without cruelty. A boy asked whether the city would be nicer if the girls were in charge and she told him a city is nicest when nobody is sure who’s in charge but everyone is sure they are answerable to their neighbors. That evening she called Tomas and told him she was tired of being charming and that he could be the charismatic one this month; he told her he was trying instead to be competent. They laughed in the way siblings do when their strategies are different and both are required.

There was a night set for a scrimmage that no one called a scrimmage because people do not know a renaissance when they see one, and everyone took two steps back from calling it an exhibition because they had not yet rested enough to permit spectacle. It happened under the cracked halo of old stadium lights that had been paid for with a fundraiser disguised as a birthday party for a woman who hated birthdays, in the field that had earned a reputation for being safe only if you were either very fast or very young. Lila arranged her unit’s routes so that the officers who liked to be photographed would, with no insult intended, find themselves solving a parking problem elsewhere. Mira signed a form permitting a civic event that did not exist. The locksmith looked at his tools and decided they would be happier on his bench than on his belt. Ezra counted boys in the morning and counted them again at dusk, which is a habit mothers have taught boys who become fathers without admitting it.

He had not intended to stand in the center circle and say anything, but the city had taught him that if you do not say something, the wrong person will. Tomas walked to the middle of the field with his palms open, which is a gesture that reads as harmless and is also the correct posture for catching, and he asked the noise around him to rearrange into something listenable. He did not say history or hero or rights or duty. He asked anyone who had ever put their shoulder against a door and felt it yield to walk a step forward. He asked them to remember what it felt like when it moved, the ridiculous intimacy of wood changing its mind because your weight had been respectful. He asked the camera operators to give their batteries a rest because sometimes beauty does its own recording. He asked the girls who had practiced three afternoons a week until their legs had opinions if they would like to go first, and the girls nodded with an economy of motion that is the envy of saints, and they passed the ball around the circle with a precision that made the old men shake their heads for the pleasure of it.

The ball itself did not come. Anaïs had carried it once into the center of a room full of good-throated people and had watched their faces do the thing you are not supposed to force faces to do. She kept it in its case now and brought a different one from the archive, a cousin without a lineage, and handed it to Tomas with the instructions you give someone when you are willing to trust them for an hour but not for a cause. He understood and was grateful for the sting of her stinginess. They played until sweat looked good and until two boys who had come to make fun of anything that looked like yearning stopped making fun. They played until the Book’s cameras, which had been instructed quietly to permit a certain amount of practice under the rubric of public wellness, learned the shape of a circle at speed and decided it was not dangerous. They played until Lila had to put her hand out to stop a woman from crying because the woman’s tears were about a daughter who had left rather than about the game and crying at the game would sour it.

Backlash came that week dressed as reason. A group that had gotten very good at naming things before anyone else could name them called itself the Glass Choir and began to say in thick syllables that respect had become theater and theater had become a cover for something they preferred to call recruitment. They had a slogan you could put on a pin and they had a list of generous donors and they had a spokesperson who had been trained not to blink too often while lying. They produced a little animation explaining how a circle looks like a cell looks like a cell, and how any practice of coordination outside state auspices was an invitation to the old ghosts to come back with better shoes. The Book gave them three days of kindness before it noticed their numbers were boastful and their verbs were disappointedly energetic. Mira declined to debate any of them because she did not intend to teach her opponents how to be charming. Lila removed a boy’s Glass Choir pin as gently as a grandmother removes a thorn and told him, in the exact tone his mother would have used, that he could pin it back on if he decided he liked being told what to think.
