The bus stop man found him again, the one with the developer taps and the midnight gift of riddles, and this time he gave himself a name: a small sound like a pebble skipping twice and then sinking. He told Tomas there were others who knew the maintenance code and that he had been selfish, keeping it as a parlor trick during floods, and he was feeling generous enough to become a mentor. He showed him a panel that did not exist for anyone who did not press two points and hold their breath between a heartbeat and a story, and he let him see the threads that had begun to form between rings that had whispered please to one another the day of the flood. It looked like a nervous system and like a fence and like a rumor if you stared too long. He told Tomas not to try to own it. He told him he would fail at not owning it. He told him the trick would be to stop before failure became luxury. Tomas wanted to ask for a history and a rule and received instead a fig and a suggestion to eat it before he inspected it for symbolism.

His mother insisted on a party when the water went fully away. She called it a party because she knew banquets were for people who wanted to talk about speeches later, and besides, she had no time for speeches when the fish had to be brought out on time. She invited only the people she was prepared to clean up after: her son and his sister and two neighbor ladies who knew where she kept the plates and, without being asked, Lila and Ezra and the locksmith and, because she was wicked in this very particular way, Mira. Mira came and stood in her small kitchen and said nothing that would make gossip later and everything that made it impossible for the hostess to hate her. She ate the fish and the bread and an orange she peeled as if it would be rude to let anyone else do it, and at the door she told the mother the untruth all bosses tell the mothers of their problematic men: He is careful. The mother, who had been told truth and lies enough to curate herself, did not contradict her.

That night the boy with the scar knocked on Tomas’s door with the expression children wear when they have found a problem they cannot solve without the complicity of someone older who will pretend not to be excited. There was a court under the viaduct where the old men played cards and the young men learned the geometry of trouble, and someone had come with a can of paint and drawn a square that made the shape of the drills into a logo and put a price on it. The boy wanted to know if he should tear it up or charge a tax. Tomas stood in the doorway and examined his pride for the telltale heat of being flattered in the wrong way, and he told the boy he should do both in the right order: tear up the paint with a bucket and three friends, and then leave a price for the men who wanted to sell the circle back to people who had invented it in basements. The price would be to stand very still for a minute and ask someone older for a story that ends without a moral. The boy grinned because he suspected he was being taught to run a game without calling it one, and in that grin Tomas remembered that he had been nineteen once for six long years.

Anaïs wrote a letter she did not send. It was addressed to the ball. In it she apologized for the fuss and thanked it for being patient and told it that when she retired she would steal it and take it somewhere with no glass and put it on a table and let children touch it until it no longer mattered what anyone had agreed to tell about it. Then she tore up the letter, because dramatics are like silk—they snag on things and then you are beholden to the snag. She instead wrote a note to a girl who had looked at the crack like a scholar and told her she could have a key to the gallery on mornings when no one else was there if she promised not to be precious about her access. The girl returned with a thank-you written on the back of a grocery list, and this delighted Anaïs enough to carry her through three arguments about stairs needing to be painted.

There is a season in every city when the weather decides to be gentle while people are trying very hard to be serious, and it makes everyone’s principles look like hats in the wrong wind. They tried anyway. The Glass Choir held forums that framed kindness as a conspiracy and filled their audiences with the sorts of men who enjoy the posture of shame on other people. Mira spoke less and made her face a place where questions went to die. Lila learned a new way to say “move” with her knees. The locksmith trained an apprentice whose hands were blessedly impatient. Ezra’s wife told him she would not host any more rope in the living room unless it started paying rent. Tomas caught himself one morning rehearsing a speech he would never give and put a spoon in his mouth to shut himself up and went to the bridge and did three quiet things that did not need to be accounted for in anyone’s ledger.

Around the same time, the first person vanished using the thread the bus stop man had shown him. It was an ugly leaving, without oranges or notes. It had no accompanying flood to make the courtesy feel like a response. It looked like a coward’s trick until they found out why—an accountant in a building that made its money off a new category called compliance had decided he did not want to be part of a machine that sold people their own habits with surcharges, and he left his ring on a sink and turned the three taps and thought of a ball hitting a wall and then he was someone else’s problem. He did not come to Tomas or Lila or even to Anaïs; he went to the locksmith, because when you are about to do a foolish, brave thing you look for the person who can fix a hinge and you ask them if you’re crazy and they say yes and then they make you a sandwich. The locksmith made him a ring that would fool a door and told him to come back in three days for the better version, and in those three days the Glass Choir declared a crisis and the city pretended to be surprised, and Mira wrote three sentences that closed a window without looking like it had been there, and the accountant slept very well for the first time since he had been given a password to something that mattered.

Tomas and Lila walked once, finally, at an hour when people do not expect men and women to do anything but sleep or sin. They did neither. They walked the long curve of the river that had lately made itself famous, and they told each other five tiny unimportant truths and did not discuss the way they had begun to carry one another’s reflexes. She pointed at a building that used to be a bathhouse and now sold coffee with insufficient apology for charging rent for conversations, and he pointed at a corner where a boy had dropped a ball in a way he would not forget. They did not touch because touching at that hour in that city carries with it a grammar they had not earned and did not want to borrow; they stood at the marker for the flood of twenty years ago and pretended not to do the math for their ages then. When they parted she said, as if it were an inventory item, that she disliked the word brave when applied to men who were doing what ought to have been less interesting. He told her he would consider being boring for a week. They laughed quietly for the sake of the sleeping.

The city turned a corner without announcing it, and the fact that no one noticed was the proof. Children began to incorporate circles into their play without feeling revolutionary. A market vendor stamped a little orange on the receipts of customers who had taught someone younger how to count change, and the stamp became a thing people compared at parties and then forgot. The Book developed a way to anticipate when someone was about to step on someone else’s heel and gently slowed one of them by showing the weather on a screen for half a breath longer than necessary. The ordinance survived with its italics and its dental work, and the choir kept singing and people bought the pins because pins are pretty whether or not they tell lies. The ball stayed in its case and smiled its crack at cameras, and Anaïs began to say the word retirement out loud in a way that felt like the letter R had been properly sharpened. Mira had a jacket altered so she could raise her arms higher without looking like she intended to hug someone, and she wrote in her yellow pad: permit, audit, forgive, repeat, and put three question marks around the third word because she knew the third word would cost her later.

He took the hex key from the windowsill on a Thursday and put it in his pocket without the red box because pockets, not boxes, had always been where men have kept their inheritances. On the way to his mother’s he stopped at the bench where the pigeons were braver than men, and he drew a diagram on the back of a flyer for a market that promised artichokes at a price that made farmers laugh, and he showed it to a girl who had lost a tooth that afternoon and was collecting opinions about whether she looked like a pirate. He told her that the problem with respect is that it feels too much like softness and too little like leverage, and she told him she didn’t know those words yet and he told her good, keep it that way for a while. He felt, for the first time since he had put the ring down in a small room with blinking lights, that there might be a version of a city he would be proud to be old in. Then a text arrived from Ezra that said in seven words what men who cannot afford grammar say when their day has turned: They took the shop. With a smile.

They had come while the locksmith was showing a girl with a braid how to clean the mouth of a lock with a trick that involved patience and an old toothbrush and a respect for mouths. They had brought a paper that had been written by a person who did not know how to carry keys without looking ridiculous. They had asked him questions that were not questions and had smiled each time he answered in a sentence longer than a verdict. They had unplugged his lathe and his little radio with a sigh that told the room it would be better this way. They had found the teapot with the chips and left it because it was a teapot and they were sentimental about households when they were doing things that injured them. They had told him not to leave town in a voice that made clear leaving town would be proof of the wrong thing. They had confiscated his incomplete rings because the law prefers its lies to be finished. They had left the shop looking temporarily larger and used, like a shirt after a dance. The locksmith stood in the doorway with his hands clasped as if at a funeral and told the girl he would finish teaching her to seat a pin in the afternoon somewhere drier.

Tomas went home and looked at the developer mode like a man looks at a gun he has promised not to keep loaded, and he did not press the taps because the room had begun to smell of tragedy and he had vowed, to nobodies and to himself, that he would not be the person who brought tragedy into rooms unless tragedy had already arrived uninvited. He put the hex key on the table like a set of intentions he was not yet ready to say out loud and called Lila with the economy that makes colleagues of people who have twice lied to protect each other in compatible ways. She told him to meet her on a corner where the Book’s eyes liked to blink. He brought two oranges and the paper with the diagram and the old toothbrush because it felt funny to carry a weapon that had once been useless. They stood together and watched the light do that trick it likes at that hour, turning everyone into the sort of person you hope you are in better stories, and she said, with a patience she did not like having to use on her own mouth, that the next thing would be crueler and more boring, and that they would need to be good at both refusing and yawning. He told her he had practiced both his whole life without awards. She touched his sleeve with two fingers, a gesture that could not be misread by any camera, and walked away to file a report that would not be read by anyone who mattered and would be found by someone who would think they had discovered a small proof of decency. The oranges sat briefly in his pocket like two suns, and he decided to count that, for now, as a surplus.

The morning broke on glass and steel, the city bright and hard. Runlights stitched between towers like impatient comets, ferrying slogans: service, unity, her. It was always her—every face on billboards an elected smile, every elevator whispering back the latest from the Book, the public ledger and noticeboard and mirror where lives were supposed to stay pinned. He rode up in one of those whispering elevators, eyes on the scuffed toes of his shoes, listening to the voice of the building tell him which floor he belonged to.

“Ministry of Civic Flow,” the voice chimed, clean as a bell and somehow satisfied with itself. “Administrative subfloor, records, postings, deletions. Good morning, Tomas Rook.”

He adjusted the thin ring on his index finger, the Book-ring, the hot little shackle that made sure he was never fully alone. The ring warmed gently, a pulse against the skin that could be polite or urgent depending on what was demanded of him. He had been told once that the ring measured loyalty in microvolts—your enthusiasm, your compliance, your little daily offerings of like and share and kneel. He worked for women who believed in such measures, who believed the city would not hold together without them. Maybe they were right. He didn’t have the power to argue, he had only the dates and times of other people’s lives.

He stepped out into the corridor, then into the open space of the Ministry floor. Women in tailored suits walked fast between glass-walled conference boxes, their hair and shoes making a fine sound on polished concrete. The plants along the edge of the atrium had their own watering schedule posted on the Book; one of the interns was already checking the soil with a digital wand. He never knew the names of the interns, they came in clusters and left in clusters, sharp and quick and immediately friendly and then gone. He knew every one of their profile pictures.

At the desk, he paused to look down into the atrium below, the murals of victory curling around the walls. A bronze ball was carved over the main door, a throwback to the old leagues, the final symbol appropriated after the Charter. Women had taken the game and made it their own, cleanly, proudly, with a flag that was half stadium lights and half rising sun. There was a museum across town where the first women's championship ball sat under glass on a velvet pillow. At least that was the picture. His father had taken him there when he was small, before it became impolite to be seen in the Hall unless you were in uniform or escorted. He remembered the hush of the room and the ball, scuffed and brown but more precious than jewels.

“Tomas,” said a voice like something unsheathed. “You’re late.”

He turned. Mira Vost was not a tall woman—one had to be careful with assumptions—but she carried weight like the anvil under the coin. Her hair was white though she was not yet fifty, the white that certain women wore as a banner. She had been in four administrations and looked likely to survive more. She wore a pin shaped like a clock, and she always reminded him that she had time.

“I’m sorry, Chancellor,” he said, because she insisted on the title even in private. “The elevator lingered.”

“The elevator does not linger. It delays for security. You will remember the difference.”

He nodded, hands already moving toward the tablet on which her day lived. In the narrowness of his half-cubicle, between the glass and the door, he took down notes as she slid her jacket onto the back of her chair and began to dictate.

“There was vandalism last night,” she said. “Hall of Heritage. An artifact missing. The feeds are alive. We will contain this. Draft me a statement for noon: outrage measured by specificity; sorrow for history; promise of consequence. Insert a line about legacy belonging to all citizens, to blunt the class criticism. Avoid the phrase ‘boys with toys.’ I would not have used it, but the Mayor has. Could you look any paler? Drink something.”

He swallowed. “Which artifact, Chancellor?”

Her mouth tightened. “A ball.”

His hand stopped on the tablet. He knew which ball before she said it. Of course he did. There were others in the Hall—rackets, medals, the first ceramic baton from the relay in the year of the Fires—but only one ball mattered to everyone. A case of velvet, a liar’s clear wall, the signatures of the first ten captains etched in an arc like a crown. His chest had a small, unhelpful ache in it.

“In the Book, it’s trending under three different tags,” he said mechanically. “We can consolidate. Limit the spread of rumor.”

“Do that,” she said. She had already pulled up her own feed on the wall screen, her face reflected ghostly over the text. “Make sure the official account posts the right image. I don’t want that ugly photo from the centennial. And call the Hall to confirm the timeline. They will be in shock. Insist anyway.”

He nodded. He felt the pulse of the ring, a curt attention-please from a thousand voices. He looked down.

Mandatory Poll: Where do you place the theft on your scale of betrayal? Choose one. The ring pulsed again, encouraging him to hurry. He clicked an answer without reading; choice had lost flavor years ago.

He pulled up the Book’s admin view on his terminal. It was not the main admin console—he was a secretary, not a Keeper—but he had certain privileges granted on a need-to-please basis. He could see trending data, language clusters. He could sense, faintly, the heat of the city's mood. Today the heat was a red name: the ball, the Ball, the folly, the crime.

Lila Qadir leaned on the partition. “Heard?”

He flinched, then forced his shoulders to unknot. Lila didn’t wear a suit, she wore a uniform, and it made a different statement. The Ministry badge sat on her chest like a seal on wax. Her hair was shaved at the sides and plaited down the back. They had known each other since the flood, when she pulled him off a bus roof with a rope and cursed like a poet while she did it.

“I heard,” he said. “You’re not assigned to this floor.”

“Not officially.” Her smile was quick and dry. “Mira wants someone to stand by the door today and look like a consequence. I drew the short stick. Or long, depending. Depends who notices.”

“Mira always notices.”

“It’s her hobby. What’s yours, Rook?”

He looked away before the answer could stick his throat shut. He had, as hobbies, secret disloyalties: hitting a ball against the wall of his kitchen with a rolled-up pair of socks at two a.m.; saving old newspaper clippings; memorizing the names of anonymous men who were temporarily significant and then vanished from the feed. He shrugged. “Drafting speeches.”

“Don’t be glum,” she said. “You do it well.”

“Thanks.”

He watched her in the glass. She was looking at him as if she could pick up off him any unspoken thing. Soldiers sometimes had that knack. Or guards. She pointed with her chin at his hand. “Your ring’s blinking.”

“It always is.”

“Like a heart.” Lila leaned closer, not quite friendly, not quite not. “You see the Hall feed? There’s a rumor the ball wasn’t signed at all. That the signatures were added after, when the Charter was signed, to make the myth smooth. That the original had a crack. You ever notice a crack?”

“I was a child,” he said. He remembered his father. Soft hands, rough voice. Cheering at the wrong time during a match and then laughing at himself for it. “I wasn’t looking for cracks.”

“You’re looking now,” she said mildly, and moved on down the corridor to where two women were arguing about meeting times. She became a consequence and the arguing stilled.

His ring required him to witness a statement from the Mayor; he clicked the witness without reading. He opened a call to the Hall of Heritage and waited until the screen resolved to a tired face. The curator, gray hair pulled back, glasses catching the light.

“We are closed,” she began. “We are closed and grieving.”

“I’m calling from the Ministry,” he said. “Civic Flow. On behalf of the Chancellor, I need to confirm the details. The ball is missing?”

“Call it theft,” she said. “Elegance in language won’t bring it back.” She blinked and then seemed to see him, to see his ring. “You’re Tomas Rook. You came here once with your father. You stood on tiptoe to see better. He lifted you and the guard told him not to carry you because of ‘policy.’ He put you down, and you had the sense to stand still.”

“I—,” he said, and felt like a page torn out of an old book. She smiled at his surprise.

“I remember what matters,” she said. “This city wears amnesia like a tiara. My name is Anaïs Vel. Come to the Hall, Mister Rook. Don’t ask me why on a channel someone else might be listening to. Come to the back door. Bring coffee. The good kind.”

He glanced at Mira, visible through her office wall, and at Lila, now watching the elevators. “I shouldn’t.”

“And yet,” Anaïs said softly, “you will. The Book is thirsty today, and you look like a man who needs to drink something that isn’t salt.”

He went. He took the Chancellor’s notes with him, because absence could be explained if it was packaged like diligence. He took two coffees, hot and dark, and he walked the long seven blocks to the Hall because walking was less suspicious than requisitioning a car. The city had the bright under-skin of a festival in panic: vendors shouting about limited commemorative pins, children whispering about the theft as if it were a song. A woman in a yellow coat asked him to take a photograph of her standing with the mural. He did, and she thanked him as if kindness might pay him back.

The Hall was set back from the street, white stone and columns like a temple, nothing to do with sport at all. The side door was painted to look like a door you weren’t supposed to see. He knocked with his knuckles in the pattern of a child, three-twos and a pause. It was foolish and worked.

Anaïs Vel opened. Up close she looked like sawn wood: rings of years visible, sturdy and beautiful. She smelled faintly of paper and oil. Behind her, the Hall glowed coldly.

“Come,” she said. “We have somewhere to sit where the cameras are less intrusive.”

He followed her through a gallery of uniforms and shoes, medals in their boxes and the larger medals that were buildings. The empty case came into view like an insult. The velvet was bare. He could see the outline where the ball had been, a shadow circle. The little plaque still read: WHEN WE BEGAN, WE BEGAN TOGETHER.

“That was never true,” she said, catching his glance. “We began and some people were told to stay at home and cheer, which is not the same as beginning anything. Your people—no, don’t flinch—your people made a lot of noise in those days.”

“Men with opinions,” he said dryly. “Rare phenomenon.”

“Don’t play humble,” she snapped, kind. “It doesn’t fit.”

She took him into an office that contained a stool, a philodendron, and a lot of dust. She took the coffee. She watched him watch the dust.

“Do you want to hear the list of who is under suspicion,” she said, “or the list of what is under suspicion?”

He considered. “What.”

“The Book,” she said immediately. “The ring. The guards. The fit of the case. The alarm’s wiring. The notion that the ball existed in the present tense in any meaningful way.” She drank. “And me.”

“You?”

“I was seen in the gallery late. With the ball. Looking at it. I have done that before. I am a curator. But this morning intention is assigned by last known direction.”

He opened his mouth to ask something brave, but she nodded toward his ring. “No. We talk about brave things out loud when we want to be seen. And we will, but not now. Tell me: Do you think you could leave the Book?”

His throat tightened. He touched the ring. In certain houses it had to be worn always; in others it could be taken off during prayers. He did not pray. “Leave? It’s illegal.”

“I asked could, not should. The ball had a chip in it, Tomas. I am old enough to find that ridiculous because it was once just a ball and a game was a game. But chips creep into everything. The chip identifies the artifact. The chip opens the case. The chip says: I am here. When it is not here, the chip says something else. It says: unpair. It says: if this is gone, what else could be gone. Do you understand?”

He thought of the console at his desk. The admin view. The faint sense of heat. The hidden settings he had never dared ask about. The Keepers had their own rooms. The Keepers had tattoos with QR codes under their hair. “I might.”

Anaïs leaned forward. “Something happened when that ball left this building. A small hole was punctured in the Book’s net to let the alarm write out, and the hole didn’t close. There’s a maintenance speed in the system when panic is high. Things are allowed to happen because making people wait might cause more noise. That is the only reason I asked you to come. You weren’t the fastest messenger I could ask. You were the one I remembered being quiet as a boy, watching like someone who believes in something. I would like you to consider believing in this: there might be a way to step out of the field. But only while the hole is an unhole, when it looks like a necessary emptiness. Do you understand?”

His heart did a very old thing. It flapped against his ribs, a bird that had realized its cage was made of string. “Are you asking me to—”

“I am telling you what I saw,” she said quietly. “And telling you that if I were young—not in my bones but in my acts—I would pick up that hole and put it in my pocket like a key. It will close. Oh, and for what it is worth: No, I did not steal the ball.”

“Mira sent me to write a statement.”

“Write it,” Anaïs said. “Write words that are not lies; write words that sound like truth. And if you decide to scratch something else into the bark while you are at it, well. I cannot stop you. This city is stratified by the difference between armistice and apathy.”

Her words made him feel both scolded and knighted. He stood. He walked back through the hall, looking at the absence until his eyes watered. He wrote the statement leaning on a pillar in the lobby, using phrases that felt like pebbles: we share this grief; history is a house we all live in; we will light every room. It was not lies. It was not enough.

On the way out, he paused. There was a scratch on the base of the case, a place where the metal had been hit—not hard enough to dent, but enough to leave a burr. He crouched and touched it. His finger came away gray.

He smelled his finger. Tin. Dust. He looked under the case’s rim, because he was foolish and curiosity might yet be a sacrament. There, under the seam, a tiny socket. Hexagonal. Old-fashioned. His father had owned a set of those keys, kept in a red metal box with the lid dented where he had dropped it. His father had shown him how to use a hex key, a slow twist, a patient twist, the knowledge that turning left at the right time would loosen something that had no interest in letting go. He had been six. He had felt like a magician.

Lila was at the door when he came back, holding up a hand to stop him. “You’re sweating.”

“It’s a warm day.”

“It is not. Where did you go?”

“To the Hall. To write the Chancellor’s statement.”

“I hope it is a good one,” she said, but her eyes were on his face, and then, quick, on his ring. The ring hummed. He felt the hum reach bone. “Everyone will share it. Everyone will say, Yes, this is the right tone. Then they will forget by dinner.”

“You are getting cynical.”

“I am getting old in a job where I do not want to get old,” she said. For a second something like a smile cracked through. “If you need a thing you don’t know you need, tell me. Or don’t tell me. I will see your posture and guess your sins.”

“Useful service.”

“To the state,” she said, bland, and turned her head when Mira’s door opened.

Inside, they performed their parts. Mira read the draft, X’d out two phrases, put in a better one, told him to post it. He posted. The Book drank the words and burped. Mira dictated directives to the security council. Lila’s shadow moved once across the glass. The city rotated like a complicated toy. Somewhere a ball was not.

By evening he was back in his apartment, which was the size of a smile you weren’t sure you wanted to return. He put the kettle on. He slid the ring off and set it on the counter so it could see the kettle and claim domesticity and therefore compliance. It was sensitive to rings of steam, it liked to think you were cooking, that you lived. He stood at the window and looked down at the street where men who still believed in conversation were talking with their hands and their faces and the slow tilt of heads. Women laughed. A man kicked an empty bottle with his heel, caught it on the point of his shoe and flipped it, and a small boy watched him with his mouth open in appreciation. The boy’s mother tapped his ear and pointed him toward the door. The man stopped, tucked the bottle under his arm as if it were a ball, embarrassed by his own grace.

He made tea. He sat. He checked the Book twice and then put it face down. He took out of his pocket the piece of gray that had come off on his finger at the Hall and turned it in the lamplight. Tiny, an almost nothing. He felt like he had stolen the moon as a nail clipping.

He had a sister in another city, a teacher of children who rarely admitted their fathers in their drawings. She called sometimes to tell him about the weather. Tonight she called to ask if he had seen the panic in the feed.

“You always hated that hall thing,” she said, laughing at herself. “You once stood in front of the case and told me it was a stupid thing to put faith in. That it wouldn’t ever make you run faster like they said.”

“I was eight,” he said.

“You were yourself,” she said. “Don’t get fired for saying the wrong true thing.”

After they said goodnight, he sat with the tea gone cold and said what he had not said aloud in years. He said: I do not belong to them as much as they think. His mouth formed the words and he understood that the forming of them was a commitment. The ring on the counter turned a low light, waiting for another performance of devoutness. He picked it up and secured it to his finger. It tightened minutely, like a promise.

The Book had a developer mode if you pressed three places on its skin while thinking of nothing. He had never found it by curiosity, he found it because a man at a bus stop had shown him once, furtive, in the hush of the flood night. Press here, here, here. Think about the sound of a ball striking a wall. Now you can see where the water goes when you pull the plug, the man had said. He had laughed then because everyone talked in riddles at two in the morning when the river was in the street. But the mode was real. It let you view the guts of your own feeds: the tags that had been attached to your name, the places your eyes had rested, the speed at which you scrolled past certain women’s faces. It let you see the pipes.

He opened it now and looked for the Hall’s feed, for the alarm’s thread. He followed it like you follow a sound in the dark. He found a note in the log: ARTIFACT 00001 UNPAIRED. He found the list of automatic actions triggered by that note: Notify Keepers. Notify Mayor. Open lens for wider capture. Reduce throttle for deletion requests for three minutes to allow for legitimate unpairing of counter measures.

Reduce throttle. For three minutes.

He put his knuckle in his mouth like a child to keep from laughing. Or crying. He watched the clock. He watched the city’s feed. He watched his own hand. He was not known for bravery; he had not been asked for it often. That was a mercy. He thought of his father and the red box and the patience of a slow twist. He thought of Anaïs Vel and the accuracy of her anger. He thought of Lila and the way she had said, If you need a thing you don’t know you need.

He typed. The Book did not like for you to leave. It used a language that pretended to be affectionate while being code: Are you sure? Are you safe? Will you miss us? Do you have somewhere to go? He kept typing. He pointed his account at a place where the Book had mis-labeled him in the past—a page that was supposed to belong to objects, not people. He created a tiny, stupid page for a missing football, and then he tried to make himself into it. The Book shuddered, confused. He pressed three places on his own pulse, thought of the sound of a ball against the wall, and found the maintenance panel. Reduce throttle. Three minutes. He sent the request again, and again. He felt the ring tighten, and then warm, and then cool, as if it was deciding whether he was still a finger worth wrapping.

The Book spat an error at him. Then it spat another. Then, with that deep reluctance with which the powerful sometimes obey their own rules, it acknowledged the shape of his trick. He watched his own account translation begin: place, person, thing. He felt a chill, as if his name had been blown on by a mouth that did not wish him well.

He stopped. He didn’t hit the last button. He didn’t pull the plug. He backed away from the precipice because you do not jump without checking the water, and because there were people who would be hurt if he vanished tonight without a plan. He breathed until he could feel his own lungs and not the ring. He went to the window and looked at the street again, the night making its own arguments with the lamps.

He would need the detail that made it clean: the hex, the key, the physical echo that the system would expect. He would need to borrow the missing ball, which was not borrowable, or borrow something that played the part. A hollow at the center of a hollow. He would need someone to watch a door. He would need someone who knew how to talk to steel. He would need to be foolish and the right kind of fast.

In the morning he went to work and smiled at the proper times and watched the Chancellor turn the theft into a call to unity. The Mayor did a tour of the Hall and wept the exact number of tears recommended by her consultants. The feeds were full; the ring got hot. He slipped a line into a memo that changed a code by one and saw the Keepers frown. He went, on his lunch break, to a basement under a gym where men played a sly version of a game with a ball made of socks and twine. He watched them in the dust and half-light and felt his heart break because it was beautiful and something you were told not to want.

“You new?” a man said, pausing for breath.

“I had a father,” Tomas said, and the man nodded as if that explained everything.

“Name’s Ezra,” the man puffed, knocking grit off his knee. “You look like someone who could fetch a thing and not get caught.”

“Sometimes,” Tomas said. “Do you know how to get a key where a key does not want to exist?”

Ezra laughed. “That is a religious question.”

“Consider me a pilgrim.”

They sat on the steps after the game because stairs were an old technology and generous. Ezra had been a courier once. He had the map of the city in his shoulders. He knew where doors liked to be. He knew where Lila Qadir liked to sit her people on cold mornings so they would feel awake. He knew a locksmith who had been made redundant by smart doors and who now made keys out of habit. He wrote the locksmith’s name on a napkin in his careful handwriting as if the napkin was an oath.

“You’ll need more than a hex,” Ezra said. “You’ll need time.”

“Three minutes,” Tomas said.

Ezra whistled between his teeth. “You’re making friends with running water. Don’t slip.”

He returned to the Ministry and typed sequences that would be part of something. He sent Lila a message that said: The Hall’s back door sticks on hot days. He did not add: Will you be there on Thursday. She did not reply, but she looked at him that afternoon as if she had read something he had written on his skin.

Anaïs Vel sent him a photograph of the empty case shot from a very low angle. In the reflection on the glass, a maintenance panel glowed green, as if it had a mind and it was thinking about disobedience. He printed the photograph and slid it into his jacket and felt sixteen and guilty.

That night, he stopped by his mother’s place in the old quarter. She poured soup and told him how her friend Reva had gotten into an argument on the Book about whether the ball deserved political asylum. He told her not to say things like that, even as jokes; she told him to stop chiding her like she had forgotten what she knew. They played cards. She asked him twelve tiny questions about his health. He told her eleven small truths. She asked him where his loyalty was, and he said, “On my feet.”

She flapped a hand. “Always complain and then go do something. You and your father both. He did not come back from doing it, you understand, and I would prefer you did.”

“I am not a fighter.”

“That is the lie small men tell themselves so they can sit down. You stand up and you make that look like a different thing. Drink your soup.”

He thought about armies, because the word had been in his head like a taste; he thought about the future like a series of rooms he could choose to open. He thought about standing in front of women who were used to being right and asking them to bend. He thought about how that would sound in his mouth. He felt tired and then less tired. He did not sleep well. He got up and bounced a sock ball against the kitchen wall until the neighbor banged on the ceiling. He apologized, out loud, to nobody.

On Thursday, the heat came early. The Hall’s back door did what old wood did. It was polite to those who knew the trick. He knew the trick now. He slipped inside with Ezra, who carried a toolbox hung with apologies. Lila was a shadow at the street, ignoring the two of them so hard she was the top of a tower in his neck. They went down the corridor that smelled of oil. The maintenance panel glowed green, like in the photograph. The hex fit. It was not theft to open a panel, he told himself, because a door wanted two states. Ezra hummed under his breath to hide the sound of the turning.

They were inside the small room where the alarms lived and breathed. He could hear the city like a tide. He set up his small, apologetic laptop. He pressed three places inside the maintenance console. He thought of a ball against a wall. Reduce throttle. For three minutes. He looked up at Ezra and myself and the world and he pressed the key you are not supposed to press because if people knew that key were there, they might start leaving.

“Last chance,” Ezra said, meaning: last chance to belong to the names you were given.

Tomas smiled, finally. “I intend to belong to more.”

He felt the Book unclasp like a hand that had been politely killing him. He felt his name shudder and then quiet. He felt the ring ringless: a cold circle with no pulse. He took it off. It came away like a scab. He closed his fist around it. He looked at Ezra and did not cry.

“Time,” Ezra whispered. The alarm’s little lights blinked in an arrangement his father would have appreciated: green green red, green green red. He reached into his jacket for the photograph where the green was greener than truth, and he folded it into a small square and put it in his mouth and chewed. It tasted of ink. He laughed and then coughed and then stood.

Outside, the city lifted its head as if startled by a breeze. Somewhere a woman at a desk pressed a button and frowned. Somewhere a Keeper’s tattoos itched. Somewhere Lila Qadir stopped being at the street and started being at the door, quiet as a blade. Her eyes met his and widened not with surprise but with an accounting. He thought he could see her tallying up his costs.

“Go,” she said without moving her mouth.

He went. He was nobody on the Book now, a hole where a person had been. He was Tomas Rook, unanchored, which in that city was a kind of insanity. He had his father’s patience in the muscles of his right hand. He had a plan that was not a plan yet. He had a ring that did not know him.

He stepped out into the bright, hard air, and the city felt suddenly like a field that had always been there under the pavement, waiting for feet. He did not run.

He would have to move like someone who could be found only if he wished it. He would have to speak like someone who did not need the Book to amplify him. He would have to find those who had spent years training their ears to hear what did not make a sound on the feed. He would have to build, perhaps, a thing with edges and a heart. He would have to teach respect without making himself into the thing he hated, which would be hard because power was shaped like that, like a mouth you slid into and then could barely keep from speaking in the same tone.

He went to the only place you went when you had done something irreversible: a bench that overlooked a court where children were pretending to be captains choosing teams, where they pointed and laughed and attempted fairness. He sat. He let himself be small in a way that had nothing to do with height. He let the city lean against his shoulder, and he leaned back. He did not check the Book. It did not check him. For the first time in a very long time, his ear heard only the wind go over the mouths of bottles in an alley, and the sound of his own name inside his head like a new ball dropped once to test its bounce. He tapped it with his toe. It came back up to meet him. He smiled that foolish smile the world calls a mistake and sometimes is a beginning.

He learned the new edges of the city by stubbing his life on them. The little machines that opened gates with a polite sigh stared through him and refused to recognize the ghost of a man where a credential should be, so he waited near a woman with her arms full of groceries and passed in her slipstream when the door hesitated on kindness. He bought nothing because money had been art on a screen for years, but a fruit vendor with hands like brick gave him a bruised pear for free when he lingered too long, and he ate it at a pace that was both grateful and guilty. He avoided the watchful rectangles over intersections because a certain tilt of glass seemed suddenly predatory, and he learned to walk a step slower and a shade lighter so the ground itself did not argue with his feet.

He went to Ezra’s locksmith, a man with a name like a cough, one of those old consonant words that sounded like it had been hammered flat and reused as a hinge. The shop was one door below street level and smelled of polish and logic, and the walls were papered with keys that had outlived their locks. The man watched Tomas with a level gaze that began as evaluation and shifted, very slightly, to concern, not for danger but for craft. He laid the ring on the counter like a tooth lost in a fight and explained what he needed, and it felt absurd to say it—an imitation of permission, a circle that would tell the city to stop shouting—but language and metal had always accommodated themselves to each other if you gave them enough patient turns.

“What you want is not a key,” the locksmith said. “It is a lie. Lies are always more expensive than keys because they must tell the truth to a larger number of strangers. What you can have from me is a ring that listens to machines and repeats back the sound they expect without understanding what it means. The price is that it will never love you the way your last ring did. It will never remember you when you slip it off. That might be a virtue.”

Tomas laughed, and the laugh made him aware of how long he had gone without letting his throat do that easily. He watched the man select a strip of spring steel and a coil of dull copper and a chip that might once have sat in a doorbell, and he asked the question he should not have, because curiosity had got into him like a second pulse. “You must have made these before. For others who wanted to go quiet.”

“I have made prettier trinkets for mistresses whose lovers wanted their own doors to open,” the locksmith said, dry as dust, and filed the edge of the ring until it looked like nothing worth stealing. “Do not mistake my work for a rebellion. I make things that function. People make revolts. They ruin my hinges when they are in a hurry and then bring me their grief like a padlock threaded through a chain, and I charge them double because grief miskeys everything.”

“Did you ever play?” Tomas asked, and the locksmith’s hand faltered just enough to prove he understood the shorthand of a city.

“My mother did,” the man said after a beat. “She sat in the high seats and shouted names until her throat was raw and good. She hated our father for teaching me to catch a ball in the alley where people could see, and she loved him for buying me a glove when she was not watching. That is the usual mathematics of home. Wear this on your left hand. It will echo the heat of your skin and produce numbers enough to pass a glance. The deeper things will not be fooled, but you do not plan to ask them for favors.”

“I plan to avoid them altogether,” Tomas said, and the man grunted approval because avoidance was a form of engineering.

The imitation ring bit cold against his finger and then warmed dutifully when he breathed on it, a mimicry of affection that did not settle in his bones. He stood a moment in the doorway of the shop, half because he was building up the courage to walk out into a city that could not call his name and half because he liked listening to the locksmith wind his lathe, the sound of something old choosing to continue. The sun made a showroom out of the street; women in bright clothes moved like banners. He put his hands in his pockets so it would not be obvious that the left hand lacked a pulse and the right one shook and was proud of it.

Mira Vost wore her white hair like a verdict and used her office like a lever She was at her desk with three screens lit and another dark, and the dark one told her the most because it reflected her face and the patience she had trained into it. A Keeper waited, still as a cutout, until she inclined her head because everyone’s time belonged to her by consent or habit, and she preferred the second. “Someone went missing inside my building,” she said without preamble, because she did not throw a topic like a song into a room; she put it down on the table, cut into it, and served appropriate portions.

“Missing is not a category,” the Keeper said, and her voice had the coldness of a river rather than ice. “We have unpaired an account not attached to a criminal ticket, and there was a maintenance window at the Hall concurrent to that unpairing. We have flagged three employees of interest. We do not say missing because we do not lose things.”

“Repeat that inside your head and tell me if it sounds like a line or a truth,” Mira said, not unkindly, because she admired a good lie even when it circulated under her name. “Which three.”

The Keeper spoke the names without flinching, and Mira did not blink either because she had trained long ago to decouple surprise from her eyelids. She heard Tomas Rook first and heard other things inside his simple syllables—quiet boy, good ear, fetches a coffee and brings back the temperature of a room with it, does not leak unless someone is dying. She heard Lila Qadir second and heard a bell rung in a bell tower, because if Lila was a suspect it was only by proximity to bad weather, and weather was her profession. She heard Anaïs Vel third and tasted iron because a city should not compel its oldest librarians to learn caution from younger women.

“Bring me the facts,” she said, and the Keeper nodded as if facts were a condiment she could produce in any quantity. “Leave the words with tails on them for when the Mayor asks me to flatter her. If a man I have paid to file papers has suddenly obtained the nerve to alter the grammar of our quiet, I want to shake his hand. Then I will decide whether to break it.”

Lila stood in the hallway outside with her back to the glass and listened to the weird democracy of shoes passing by. She had felt the flicker when Tomas went out of range, the way the air goes thin on a training climb, and she had stepped toward the gap before she knew whose shape it held. There was a discipline to not moving when your body wanted to, and it derived from older disciplines, the ones born on flood nights and in smoke and in the peculiar silence after you cut a wire and wait to learn whether you have disarmed a trap or a friend. She watched the red indicator over the west stairwell blaze and then go out. She did not change her breathing. She thought, for the first time in weeks, about sleeping in a bed she did not have to fold up in the morning.

In the Hall, Anaïs Vel met a woman who wore her hair in a braid that managed to be both austere and decorative, a compromise that summarized her posture. The woman asked questions that were polite in their aggressions, and Anaïs answered the impolite ones in her own head because it was a habit that kept her honest. She walked the Keeper past the empty case, past the plaques that told the version of history that won funding, and stopped before a photograph from a long-ago match because it pleased her to be seen looking at something that was not currently bleeding. “Did you know,” she said, as if she was talking to a friend and not a ledger with a voice, “that the paint on the original stadium railings was a mix of commercial red and a cheaper brown that some man found in a storeroom and decided not to waste, which is why the railings looked like two different memories of the same day? You can see it in this picture if you have eyes. We made a choice and we made a mess and we called it a tradition, which is how all good stories begin.”

The Keeper nodded in the precise manner of a person who had decided to let a metaphor pass by so she could shoot it later from cover. “We have footage of you in the gallery at two thirty-two,” she said. “We have the signature of an alarm you silenced at three oh five. We have your face on six of the cameras, and you stared directly into one of them as if you were trying to seduce it.”

“I was thinking of killing it,” Anaïs said cheerfully. “Staring is not seduction when the lens is older than your grandmother and twice as stubborn. I turned off an alarm because it had decided to be offended by a moth. If you would like to arrest the moth, I can find you its name. It will be something Biblical and difficult to spell.”

“You do not seem afraid,” the Keeper observed, and Anaïs smiled because it looked good on her and because she was afraid in the complicated way old people were, which meant she was afraid for the wrong things.

“I made a choice years ago not to be afraid of people who think they are history,” she said. “They keep dying on me. It is very inconvenient. The ball is gone. The case is compromised. Someone with a hex key and an understanding of torque touched it, which means someone with a father touched it, which means I will find him before you do if I choose to ask the right older women. Be efficient, dear. I am trying to set out the folding chairs for an argument.”

Tomas took his new ring to the turnstiles and learned that the city would accept a forged handshake if he did not ask for more than he deserved. He passed through doorways and was not stopped. He stood near the small screens that wanted to tell him what to buy and they decided he was uninteresting and turned their pretty faces toward someone else. He found the seam between what was enforced and what was believed, and it was wider than he had thought, a small blessing disguised as indifference. He bought a train token from a man who even the Book ignored, because the token machines wanted prettier fingers than his and because humility and copper had a friendship that had survived worse regimes than this.

On the train he sat in a corner where the light made everyone look like a painting of a better version of themselves and watched a little girl with a braid that refused its mother’s elastic. The girl was using two fingers to drum a rhythm on her own knee, a rhythm he knew without knowing he knew it until his foot answered, a pattern lifted from the old league chants, stripped of syllables and left as a heartbeat that led nowhere. Her mother noticed, not the rhythm but the man, and her eyes slid away and then back, and she saw the lack of a pulse in his ring and the shape of a careful man sitting small in a large world. She moved between him and her daughter and did not scowl. She put the girl’s hand on her own knee and let her drum there, the sound a permission that did not invest itself.

Ezra met him at the gym door and smacked his shoulder with affection that pretended to be critique. “You walked across the city with that face,” he said. “You look like a primary school teacher who has discovered his class has been swapped for wolves and is trying to decide whether to pet them or join them. Come down. We have figured out the metal of the back panel. It likes to complain in a very particular pitch when it is touched with a key five sizes too small for it.”

“You are laughing,” Tomas said, and dropped into the stairs that smelled of sweat and sawdust and the past tense of verbs that the Book had deprecated.

“We are laughing all the time,” Ezra said. “We are laughing because we are still allowed to be in the same room, and because when the ball leaves the floor here it makes a sound that is enough like the one from our mothers’ stories that our bodies relax without asking permission. Stop looking like your presence is a crack. Stand with us. That is an order you can disobey later.”

They stood, and that counted, because a courtyard and a basement and a bad hallway had become the only places respect could be built with eye contact and noise. Tomas watched a kid with a scar on his lip pivot around an invisible defender and toss a sock-ball through a square of light sharp enough to shave with. He watched a woman with a busted knee grin like a dare and then treat herself gently, which was harder than daring for some. He played a little, badly. He remembered his father’s hands shadowing his and felt that particular ache that had become less a pain and more a tuning fork, a way to find middle C inside a day full of chatter.

“Tell me a thing,” Ezra said when they were breathless enough to be honest. “Not a plan. A thing you want. Something you can say out loud that is not a commandment.

“I want to look at the ball,” Tomas said before prudence could tighten his jaw. “Not the picture on the feed or the official portrait that makes it look like an egg in an expensive cradle. The ball. The actual brown skin of it. The scuff where she said she kicked it in practice and missed on purpose to make someone laugh. The crack they denied and the signatures they smoothed over like varnish. I want to see it to know whether wanting it was the first lie I told myself.”

Ezra leaned his head against the wall and closed his eyes as if someone had smoothed a cool cloth across his forehead. “Good,” he said. “I want to throw it once with my eyes closed and hear it come back so I know everything is still symmetrical. You are an idiot to say that out loud in a building with microphones, and I am an idiot to agree. We are properly matched.”

He went to see his mother because she had asked him to come on Thursdays and bring the bread she liked from the stall where they overcharged him less than they overcharged other men. Her apartment had a plant she had somehow bullied into living and a rug his father had bought in a decade when rugs were the only thing a person could own that no one would take unless they intended to stay. She looked at him with a hunger he had not let her indulge since he was fifteen and decided honesty at home would kill him faster than silence.

“You went quiet,” she said, and he did not waste either of their supplies by denying it.

“I did,” he said. “It is quieter in the quiet than they told us it would be. I thought I would be lonely enough to eat my own knuckles, but mostly there is room for other noises. I had not heard how often my knees crack when I go up stairs. I had not heard the woman in the next building practicing her violin three floors below the note that would make the hair on my arms stand up. I had not heard my own laugh like a stranger’s.”

“You will get yourself hurt,” she said, and then shrugged because the sentence was the least interesting she could have chosen. “Someone will knock at my door and use that tone that turns mothers into paperwork. I will say I do not know anything and they will think I am lying and I will not be. You will bring me soup on Sundays and that will be the burden I bear, that I do not get to hug my child in the marketplace for fear someone will think arms are conspiracies.”

“I can stop,” he said, and her cheeks wrinkled into a shape that looked very much like the expression she wore when his father told her a joke she did not want to laugh at because it would reward him for being late.

“You can,” she said. “You can also stop seeing well because it is inconvenient to notice a hole in the ground before you step into it. I have taught children long enough to know which of my students will jump the fence to take a shortcut and which will stand in front of it and spend fifteen minutes arguing with a plank. You are a fence-jumper in your bones and a plank-arguer in your job. I let your father do one thing that he needed to do and he did not come back from doing it. You will bring me bread on Thursdays. That is my non-negotiable. If you go away and come back with your skin rearranged, do not expect me to admire the new lines. I am not obliged to enjoy your heroics.”

He promised, because promising is a form of faith and she needed him to have some that could be cashed in later. He left with the bread still warm in its paper and with the sensation that he had put his hand into a pocket and discovered it had a hole in the bottom he had not noticed. He turned toward the river because rivers make sense even when everything else is making a kind of sense that depends on bullet points. He walked past the stadium where women ran in loops under lights that had been coaxed into being beautiful, and he knew he would have to go inside soon under some pretense if he was going to do the thing he was pretending he had not decided to do.

Mira called Lila into her office late, the hour when the building’s mirrors are kinder and the air tastes like the unspoken. She poured a measure of bitter liquor into a glass and did not offer any, which was friendlier than sharing, because the hour could be mistaken for intimacy if you were not careful. “Tell me what you know that is not on the feeds,” she said, and watched Lila’s eyebrows because they read more honestly than most lips.

“I know the Hall’s back door sticks and can be persuaded not to by someone who knows where to put the heel of their hand,” Lila said. “I know I stood at the corner on Thursday and watched two men carrying a toolbox that made no sound, which is not how tools behave when they are honest. I know that a maintenance panel blinked at me as if it were winking, and I know a wink is a vulgar gesture when it comes from a device that turns tragedy on and off. You know the same, Chancellor. I know you want me to say a name so we can start the machinery that makes people feel better for thirty hours before they begin to suspect they have been given a story instead of relief.”

“You refuse to say a name in this room,” Mira said, as if she were checking a line item off a list, and Lila nodded because refusal is a form of professionalism if you do it symmetrically.

“I am counting the number of things I have forgiven you for,” Lila said, and softened the pronoun with a small smile like a footnote. “It helps keep me honest. I will add one if this conversation goes well and subtract two if you tell me you already picked the person you wanted me to betray before I came in.”

“Do not rehearse your revolution,” Mira said gently. “It makes your hair look good but it bores me. Bring me what you find. Bring me people by the ear if they are foolish. Bring me the person who stole the ball when you find them, and if it is me, bring me anyway. I have been arrested before and it made my back stronger.”

Lila stood and did not salute because salutes in this building were an amateur’s mistake. “If the person who took the ball wanted to put it back,” she said, “would you release your jaw around their throat or take a breath and help. The second is a question.”

“For the second there is no answer I can give that will make both of us like ourselves,” Mira said, and managed a smile not because she felt like it but because it was a trick she had learned young. “Ask me again when the ball has dirt on it and we can smell the grass.”

Anaïs sent Tomas a message via a method that made him smile because it was old and clever. She had written a note on paper with pencil and given it to a child in pigtails to carry to the man with the scar who managed Ezra’s door, and it said in its small, stern handwriting: Come at closing. Walk like a person with a headache. Do not bring anything sharp. If you are followed, buy two oranges and put one in each coat pocket. That way you will know whether you are using your hands out of nerves. Also, oranges are good for you and they keep secrets with dignity.

He went at closing and walked as if the light was too bright for him and as if his head could be persuaded by posture to ache less. The guard at the Hall looked like a person who had practiced arguing and then retired into a job where people made her less angry, and she nodded to him with the sort of courtesy you save for neighbors you do not like but would defend in a fire. Anaïs met him in the gallery where the busts watched the doors as if their line of sight had been engineered for suspicion, and she led him again toward the office with the dust and the plant and the stool. On the way he stopped to look at a photograph of a goal he had seen a hundred times and never noticed the woman in the background who had her hands over her mouth as if she had dropped a secret.

“It is very inconvenient when the world has faces,” Anaïs said. “Come. Do not look at me as if I am about to tell you either a bedtime story or a murder ballad. Both are true and I am tired of polarity. The ball is not here. It has not left the city. It is in a place where it is technically still inside a boundary that satisfies the anxious, and that is the kind of lie people like because it lets their spines relax without proving them wrong outright.”

“You hid it,” he said, and felt the embarrassment of being both grateful and scolded.

“I moved it,” she said. “Hiding suggests shame, while moving is a curator’s privilege and implies a plan. Look at this.” She unrolled a photograph that had been taken just after something joyful had happened and now had the atmosphere of a crime scene, which is how archives can make saints or felons out of people depending on which side of the glass you wake up. “There,” she said, tapping the margin where an absurd detail hid, the way truth prefers to do. “The bronze ball over the Hall’s entrance is not a casting. It is not hollow. It is two shells cradling a third. Someone decided they needed a matryoshka and then forgot to properly enumerate their dolls. The smallest shell is the measure of the real ball. It is not the real ball, but it is close enough to fool anyone who is looking without touching. If someone had a father who taught them the hour and the patience, they could make a swap that satisfied every eye but their own. If someone wanted to create a hole in a net and needed an honest reason for the net to make room, they might borrow an absence from a myth.”

“You wanted the three minutes,” he said, and she took off her glasses to rub the bridge of her nose, because old people were tired all the time with good reason.

“I wanted to see whether a person like you would find them,” she said. “Do not be vain. I had five names. Three of them are men. You were the least likely to tell me to go to hell when I asked for a favor. That is my method: respect, bribery, and accuracy. We will put it back. I do not intend to feed the city to the wolves for a metaphor. Between the taking and the returning, I would like to see whether I can alter the angle by which people remember that object. There is a crack. I am not senile. Let it show in one photograph. Let it live as something that had to survive and did and got its scars honestly. If your Chancellor wants to pin a new slogan to the idea, let her do it with her own fingers and see whether the pin draws blood.”

“You are asking me to become a thief for a truth,” he said, and the word thief did not sit well in his mouth because he had always been the sort of boy who brought the chalk back to the ledge after drawing where he shouldn’t.

“I am telling you that respect is sometimes taken without a receipt,” she said. “Take it and sign your name later if you survive the taking. If someone is going to hunt you in the meantime, you will need a woman who opens doors with her shoulder instead of her keys. Do you have one?”

He thought of Lila and the way she had said, Go, without breaking the line of her mouth into an expression that could be used against her in some future hearing. He nodded because naming her would be an injury and because Anaïs did not need the name to understand the shape of the help. Anaïs touched his forearm like touching wood before a storm. “Good,” she said. “Do not make her explain why she chose to do it. Give her something cleaner to say when someone points a mirror at her. Do not be poetic in front of someone with a badge.”

The morning the Book noticed him properly was not the morning he left but the day after, when the numbers that meant: Tomas read this, Tomas witnessed that, Tomas approved the phrasing of a condolence—stayed zero long enough to be embarrassing at a meeting. The Book did not do embarrassment, but the people with their eyes on it did, and they pretended it was a button you could push to produce compliance. Messages arrived for his old name like wisps of smoke finding an open window and being surprised the room they expected was a field. The imitation ring on his finger hummed twice, an attempt to synchronize, and then gave up with an indifference that made him feel both proud and stupid.

Mira convened a panel with a smile that promised biscuits and put in front of them a map of the city with a hole in it exactly the size of a man who carried pencils and wore soft shoes to work. “You will say it is nothing,” she said, and they did, and then they said it was probably a death, and she said no because deaths were laborious in a city that insisted on certainty, and then someone suggested a vacation, and she said she did not hire men who took vacations because the work made them too nervous to enjoy beaches. “It is an unpairing without a ticket,” she said finally, her voice like a clear bell in a room that had been muffled on purpose. “Those are supposed to occur only for maintenance or death. This one occurred concurrent to a theft and in the presence of people who are not known for stealing. I want the person in charge of vocabulary to tell me what we call this.”

“An accident,” said the Mayor’s liaison, because nothing comforts a person more than the idea that no one intended harm. “A placeholder. A glitch.”

“Glitches are for lights in hallways and teeth that bite their own tongues,” Mira said. “We will get him back if he wants to be gotten. If he does not, we will make a statement this afternoon reminding everyone that the city loves their choices. In the meantime, stop turning knobs at the Hall as if you could make guilt come out of a pipe. It makes the cameras twitch, and twitching makes people look at cameras, and the last thing I want is to teach people to see.”

Lila stood in the corridor after and felt the weight of being a stone in moving water, the way force complicates itself around you. Her supervisor, a woman who had the face of a saint and the habit of a butcher, touched her arm with two fingers and left the imprint of a future reprimand as if oil could stain through a sleeve. “We have a warrant for a name,” the supervisor said. “We will go to his mother’s house and stand outside in a way that makes the neighbors watch. If he is there, he will rush. If he is not, she will tell us that he is not, and we will pretend to believe her, because we prefer the look of ourselves when we are magnanimous. You like this boy. I can smell it. Put that smell somewhere else until Friday.”

“I like that he knows where to stand when a bus starts to slide,” Lila said, a careful sentence that contained three truths and no admission. “I like that he listens when older women talk like water under a boat. I do not like this job when it makes me catalog what I like about people who do not fit in rooms I wrote the plans for. I will do the thing you are asking. I will not look like a person who enjoys it.”

They knocked at his mother’s door with flat knuckles because the city had taught them not to pound unless they had a camera pointing the other way. His mother answered wearing a cardigan that had survived three fashions and a look that would have sent nuns to their rosaries. She let them in and offered tea because hospitable refusal was her favorite sport, and she stood in the doorway of her own kitchen until Lila produced a polite, official need to be inside of it. “He went out with bread,” his mother said, and Lila loved her a little for the sentence’s ambiguity. “He will bring me soup on Sunday. We will play cards and he will cheat once so I do not feel I have gotten old and dull. Do not look at my photographs and pretend any of the faces will help you. The Book did not stop by here to bless them. We do the blessing ourselves on Fridays.”

“Your son is unpaired,” the supervisor said, as if that were an accusation, and his mother made a small sound, almost a laugh, because the word was rude if you saw it with its clothes off.

“My son is in the world,” she said. “That has always been his problem. He will have to decide how much of it to embrace and how much to argue with. I do not think he will choose the right balance. He never did. He might make me proud in a year if you give him enough rope to ruin a fence with.”

Tomas stood outside three doors down and listened through a lattice, because the old buildings had retained their talents for telling you about the people inside them, and he learned something about his mother again that made his chest rearrange itself for a minute. Lila did not turn her head, but she let her gaze go sideways and catch the line of the lattice, and he felt the very slight permission that lived in the set of her shoulders. He went away not hurriedly, because haste wakes up dogs, and turned his mind toward the bigger theft that now had a deadline the shape of a press conference.

He met Anaïs at the base of a ladder no one had touched in twenty years because the caretakers had been told that certain acts were now beneath them and they believed it. Ezra leaned against a column that knew its own weight, and he held a bag with a coil of rope in it as if he were taking a serpent for a walk. The bronze ball over the entrance was backlit against a sky that had the audacity to be lovely during a scandal, and a few girls in team jackets stood across the street taking pictures of themselves with angles curated to place the empty in the frame like a charm against an exam. The plan was not glamorous, which is how plans want to be if they intend to work twice.

He climbed. The ladder talked to him in the language of rust and complaint. He felt the uncanny steadiness that comes over a body when it decides it will not die and therefore might as well behave. He reached the seam Anaïs had described and found that it was exactly where it had been in the photograph because secrets are not clever enough to move on their own. The hex fit like a memory. He turned with the patience of his father humming in his wrist, slow, slow, slow, because hurrying has a tone and bolts hate it. The outer shell came away like a hat being removed before an anthem. The second shell had been painted to look like reverence and was simply a shield. The inner, smaller form was the measure, and it was exquisite and wrong.

He held it and imagined for a minute the room where someone had decided to make this so their conscience could be clean for an hour. He lowered it with the rope and the breath he had been saving since he cut the Book’s cord, and Ezra caught it with the reverence of a boy catching a thing he’s been promised will change his height. Anaïs had cotton prepared to keep the vulgarities of the ground from touching it. Tomas took the synthetic sphere they had brought—a charity ball, too smooth, too eager—and fitted it where the measure had been. He reassembled the shells, and the bronze face over the door looked down on the street with the same expression as before, because art knows how to wear lies like lipstick.

When he came down, Lila was there with her hands in her pockets, pretending to be a stranger who might be in the mood to observe a museum doing museum things. He put his palms against the stone to show her that he had not pocketed anything obvious, and she smiled, small and private, because she had never believed in innocence as a strategy. “You are on a ladder in a city that thinks vertigo is a philosophy,” she said. “If you fall, I will report that you did it on purpose and use your death in a presentation to frighten interns.”

“If I live,” he said, “will you use my life to do anything but frighten interns.”

“Yes,” she said, and he tried not to let the heat of that syllable make him clumsy. “I will use it to make someone above my pay grade stop talking.”

They went inside together for the first time since he had gone quiet, and the Hall welcomed them like a building that had decided to forgive. Anaïs nodded once, briskly, because open sentiment slowed hands, and she took them through a service corridor that had learned to be humble. In the room with the dust and the plant and the stool, she set the measure on the table and then, without flourish, pulled aside a cabinet that hid a safe people had assumed was decorative because it had been sitting under a map for so long. She opened it with a key she gave a name aloud, because doors like to be addressed before they yield. Inside, wrapped in linen and arrogance, sat the ball.

He thought he had prepared himself. He had rehearsed both disdain and tears. He had decided to feel nothing but the shape of it against his palm, because abstract feelings seemed disrespectful. What he felt instead was the pleasant bewilderment of a hand holding something round and the shock of the human scale of a myth. It was not larger than his memory had made it. It was not smaller, either. It was simply a ball, with the lines of its construction visible, the leather worn to a softness his fingers recognized from the sleeve of his father’s jacket in winter. The crack was there, exactly where Anaïs had promised it would be, a hairline imperfection that ruined the story and made it better if you had a stomach for the truth.

“Right there,” Anaïs said, and her voice shook for the first time that day and probably the last. “She kicked it during a practice in a week when she thought quitting might be the real victory and the ball hit the post and came back and hit her in the mouth, and she laughed so hard she sat down. She told me that story in this room and swore me to secrecy because the story works better without the laugh. I am too old for stories that work.”

“What do we do with that knowledge,” Lila asked, and the practical shape of her voice steadied the room.

“We put it back with its crack facing camera,” Anaïs said. “We let the myth adjust. You do not correct an ocean, you let the tide look like its own idea. Tomas, you are going to carry it to the case, and your hands will be on it, and no one will be able to make a clean sin out of that, because they will want the picture of the ball more than they want the picture of you. Lila, you will stand where people can see your profile and decide not to lie to themselves about why you let him pass. Ezra, you will go home and hide that expression you are wearing so your wife does not accuse you of being in love with a circle.”

“I am,” Ezra said, and for once he did not make it a joke, because worship was a poor habit for men and a fine one for citizens.

They walked the way a procession would if it had been invented by clerks and soldiers and old women and one man who was trying to learn humility. The corridor was short enough not to ask courage and long enough to make you consider your posture. Lila went ahead and the guards saw her and pretended to enjoy her authority. The Book would not catch this because Anaïs had turned down the volume of its seeing for three minutes on account of a scheduled dusting. The case yawned politely because the hex had been talked into cooperation. He set the ball down, and his hand lingered an instant too long, and he said goodbye not to an object but to the idea that he had not made choices yet, because after this every choice would be compared to this one and measured for its balance.

After, people in the lobby clapped because they did not know whether to whistle. Someone sang a line from the Book that was not actually in the Book and got away with it. anaïs stood as if she were vibrating slightly, like a string under the finger of someone who knew the exact pressure to produce clarity. Lila leaned on a pillar and raised one eyebrow at him as if to say: Put your hands in your pockets now, because men who have just done something in public and leave their hands visible look either weak or predatory, and I would prefer you looked like a person who had bought oranges and walked home.

He obeyed. He bought oranges because it was now a talisman as well as a snack, and he put one in each coat pocket and felt the weight like something honest among all the practiced fictions. He walked back into the city he had made worse for some people and better for none yet, which was not as consoling as he had hoped it would be. The imitation ring was light on his finger and did not care about any of this. The Book might know his face again if it wanted to, because cameras learn fast when they are told to. He had put his hand on the ball and now he had to live with the way that had arranged his future.

In her office, Mira watched the clip the Hall’s feed had produced and had to admire it, which was irritating. The crack was evident if you knew where to look, and the line the official account had posted about history being a house and lighting rooms had been repurposed as if they had been waiting for it. The comments were elegant in their performative grief and then grew toothy in their relief, because relief comes with a right to scold. She paused the clip on a frame where Lila’s jaw was a geometry problem and Tomas’s hand was still a shadow near the ball, and she felt the ache in her face that meant she was going to have to acquiesce to a narrative she had not authored.
