A second insult came as funding: a man with a smooth ring and a laugh he had practiced offered to underwrite printed sheets and a little office in a building that did not yet have rats and would therefore require rent on time every month. Tomas listened politely because his mother had taught him that charity is often just attention someone wants to record, and he declined with the kind of grace that would not earn him enemies now but would cost him later when the man needed, as such men always do, to be seen tearing down what they had failed to purchase. He took the insults as a sign of health. Insults only bother the living.

Anaïs Vel was summoned to a room with glass and subtraction and suffered the indignity of being told to sit by a man who had learned to be comfortable without shoes somewhere expensive. He told her, with the confidence of someone who could hire three replacement curators for the cost of the carpet, that the Hall had always thrived when its narrative had been clear and that the recent flirtations with ambiguity, while thrilling to certain donors, had confused the base. She saw three things at once: his vowels, which had not been taught to pronounce the names of the corners of the city; his cufflinks, which made her hands itch for pliers; and the little white at the edges of his nostrils that told her he had lifted something heavy recently and found it heavier than his body believed things to be. “We sell clarity because clarity pays for the electricity,” he said, and she said, in the voice she had used on sons and husbands and plumbers who wanted to be paid twice for the same accident, that the ball’s crack would stay visible because honesty keeps the lights on longer. He told her there would be a vote. She told him he had already lost it and he asked her to leave because politeness is a leash they hand you when they are about to pull. In the elevator she allowed herself a small wicked grin because she had always loved elevators for their little theatre of containment; in the reflection she looked every inch the old woman in a tapestry with a pair of scissors in her lap, and the thought cheered her enough to get her through the next meeting with a junior who wanted to call her “auntie” and did not.

In the basement gym the game grew a second skin. The drills that had been drills in public and survival in a flood became practice for something no one wanted to name because names tell on you, and yet people need to point at a thing to talk about it. Ezra called it the circuit because he liked the ugly industrial ring of the word, and everyone pretended to hate it. They began to trace the same pattern at different scales: five bodies and thirteen dots and a dotted line in chalk and then the same pattern across a square with oranges and then the same pattern inside a building where the cameras had been taught to love symmetry and therefore watched all the right wrong things. Tomas did not call it anything. He called the numbers. He sat down with a girl whose father had been a policeman before the Book, and he showed her that the moment you resist is often the moment you double the noise in the room, and she taught him that sometimes noise protects. They were inventing a form of math that might, in another family, have turned into a better version of war.

Lila began the week believing she could hold everything she was being asked to hold with one hand while the other made the gestures that persuaded people the state had never meant anyone harm. By Wednesday she had to use both hands, and she did not like the feeling not because it made her look tired but because it meant something in the system had decided to act like a toddler in a doorway, insisting everyone step over it rather than getting up and moving. A new directive had arrived with important italics, reminding her to file weekly reports on informal gatherings that might “constitute emergent paramilitary formations.” The list of indicators included circles larger than fifteen people, repetitions of a call-and-response not initiated by the authorities, and the presence of fruit used as wayfinding or admission tokens. She read it twice and took a photograph and then ate it because she knew someone who would search her bin a week from now and had decided not to give them the pleasure of finding it intact. When she met Tomas on her lunch break without calling it a meeting, she told him to start acting as if there were faces in every blank space, and he said he had been assuming that since childhood. She told him the word paramilitary had entered the room and he laughed, which is what a sane person does right up until someone knocks at their mother’s door with the other version of the word on a paper with teeth.

The locksmith received a formal notice alleging that he manufactured devices intended to deceive civic infrastructure and inviting him to attend a voluntary conversation at a place that had the audacity to be called Neutral House. He set the paper under a wobbly table leg and came to the basement that night with his bag of patient metal like a man going to a baptism. He told the room that if anyone wanted a ring that lied, they could have one only if they swore to treat it as a tool and not as a garment, and that if any of the boys in the back had been playing with jammers they had bought with pretend money from someone with a haircut that required attention, he would take them apart and make them read the diagrams aloud until they learned shame. One boy laughed and then, to his credit, shut up and listened. The locksmith made two more rings that hum without consent and watched Tomas not ask for one. He felt an unexpected affection for the not-asking and hid it behind a lecture about temperature and solder.

The Book, having learned to whisper please to a set of rings during a flood, attempted to generalize courtesy and embarrassed itself. For three days it sent small messages to citizens near benches where drills were happening, messages that read as if they had been written by a careful aunt: Do you need a space? Would you like us to recommend a safe path? We have noticed patterns of courtesy nearby. It did not occur to it that surveillance was easier to digest under panic and more offensive under leisure, and it learned the lesson the way machines learn anything worth keeping—through public humiliation followed by a change in the rules. Mira told the team to stop A/B testing kindness and go back to smoothing the edges of loud corners. A junior engineer, who had taught himself the maintenance taps during the flood and thought that meant something radical had happened inside him, wrote a memo suggesting the Book learn to ask the city what it wants before assuming the answer. The memo was not read aloud at any of the meetings. The junior took to visiting the bridge after work and counting oranges like stars.

Tomas’s sister, whose school had learned the art of being official and disobedient at the same time, found her pendants confiscated by a vice principal who had convinced herself that modesty was an act of aggression. The girls came to class the next day with rings tied to their shoelaces and looked the woman in the eye until she looked down and found herself smiling despite having intended to do the opposite. That afternoon their teacher took them out into the courtyard and showed them how to make circles with chalk that could be washed off quickly when someone came asking about property, and she told them to practice choosing without cruelty. A boy asked whether the city would be nicer if the girls were in charge and she told him a city is nicest when nobody is sure who’s in charge but everyone is sure they are answerable to their neighbors. That evening she called Tomas and told him she was tired of being charming and that he could be the charismatic one this month; he told her he was trying instead to be competent. They laughed in the way siblings do when their strategies are different and both are required.

There was a night set for a scrimmage that no one called a scrimmage because people do not know a renaissance when they see one, and everyone took two steps back from calling it an exhibition because they had not yet rested enough to permit spectacle. It happened under the cracked halo of old stadium lights that had been paid for with a fundraiser disguised as a birthday party for a woman who hated birthdays, in the field that had earned a reputation for being safe only if you were either very fast or very young. Lila arranged her unit’s routes so that the officers who liked to be photographed would, with no insult intended, find themselves solving a parking problem elsewhere. Mira signed a form permitting a civic event that did not exist. The locksmith looked at his tools and decided they would be happier on his bench than on his belt. Ezra counted boys in the morning and counted them again at dusk, which is a habit mothers have taught boys who become fathers without admitting it.

He had not intended to stand in the center circle and say anything, but the city had taught him that if you do not say something, the wrong person will. Tomas walked to the middle of the field with his palms open, which is a gesture that reads as harmless and is also the correct posture for catching, and he asked the noise around him to rearrange into something listenable. He did not say history or hero or rights or duty. He asked anyone who had ever put their shoulder against a door and felt it yield to walk a step forward. He asked them to remember what it felt like when it moved, the ridiculous intimacy of wood changing its mind because your weight had been respectful. He asked the camera operators to give their batteries a rest because sometimes beauty does its own recording. He asked the girls who had practiced three afternoons a week until their legs had opinions if they would like to go first, and the girls nodded with an economy of motion that is the envy of saints, and they passed the ball around the circle with a precision that made the old men shake their heads for the pleasure of it.

The ball itself did not come. Anaïs had carried it once into the center of a room full of good-throated people and had watched their faces do the thing you are not supposed to force faces to do. She kept it in its case now and brought a different one from the archive, a cousin without a lineage, and handed it to Tomas with the instructions you give someone when you are willing to trust them for an hour but not for a cause. He understood and was grateful for the sting of her stinginess. They played until sweat looked good and until two boys who had come to make fun of anything that looked like yearning stopped making fun. They played until the Book’s cameras, which had been instructed quietly to permit a certain amount of practice under the rubric of public wellness, learned the shape of a circle at speed and decided it was not dangerous. They played until Lila had to put her hand out to stop a woman from crying because the woman’s tears were about a daughter who had left rather than about the game and crying at the game would sour it.

Backlash came that week dressed as reason. A group that had gotten very good at naming things before anyone else could name them called itself the Glass Choir and began to say in thick syllables that respect had become theater and theater had become a cover for something they preferred to call recruitment. They had a slogan you could put on a pin and they had a list of generous donors and they had a spokesperson who had been trained not to blink too often while lying. They produced a little animation explaining how a circle looks like a cell looks like a cell, and how any practice of coordination outside state auspices was an invitation to the old ghosts to come back with better shoes. The Book gave them three days of kindness before it noticed their numbers were boastful and their verbs were disappointedly energetic. Mira declined to debate any of them because she did not intend to teach her opponents how to be charming. Lila removed a boy’s Glass Choir pin as gently as a grandmother removes a thorn and told him, in the exact tone his mother would have used, that he could pin it back on if he decided he liked being told what to think.

The bus stop man found him again, the one with the developer taps and the midnight gift of riddles, and this time he gave himself a name: a small sound like a pebble skipping twice and then sinking. He told Tomas there were others who knew the maintenance code and that he had been selfish, keeping it as a parlor trick during floods, and he was feeling generous enough to become a mentor. He showed him a panel that did not exist for anyone who did not press two points and hold their breath between a heartbeat and a story, and he let him see the threads that had begun to form between rings that had whispered please to one another the day of the flood. It looked like a nervous system and like a fence and like a rumor if you stared too long. He told Tomas not to try to own it. He told him he would fail at not owning it. He told him the trick would be to stop before failure became luxury. Tomas wanted to ask for a history and a rule and received instead a fig and a suggestion to eat it before he inspected it for symbolism.

His mother insisted on a party when the water went fully away. She called it a party because she knew banquets were for people who wanted to talk about speeches later, and besides, she had no time for speeches when the fish had to be brought out on time. She invited only the people she was prepared to clean up after: her son and his sister and two neighbor ladies who knew where she kept the plates and, without being asked, Lila and Ezra and the locksmith and, because she was wicked in this very particular way, Mira. Mira came and stood in her small kitchen and said nothing that would make gossip later and everything that made it impossible for the hostess to hate her. She ate the fish and the bread and an orange she peeled as if it would be rude to let anyone else do it, and at the door she told the mother the untruth all bosses tell the mothers of their problematic men: He is careful. The mother, who had been told truth and lies enough to curate herself, did not contradict her.

That night the boy with the scar knocked on Tomas’s door with the expression children wear when they have found a problem they cannot solve without the complicity of someone older who will pretend not to be excited. There was a court under the viaduct where the old men played cards and the young men learned the geometry of trouble, and someone had come with a can of paint and drawn a square that made the shape of the drills into a logo and put a price on it. The boy wanted to know if he should tear it up or charge a tax. Tomas stood in the doorway and examined his pride for the telltale heat of being flattered in the wrong way, and he told the boy he should do both in the right order: tear up the paint with a bucket and three friends, and then leave a price for the men who wanted to sell the circle back to people who had invented it in basements. The price would be to stand very still for a minute and ask someone older for a story that ends without a moral. The boy grinned because he suspected he was being taught to run a game without calling it one, and in that grin Tomas remembered that he had been nineteen once for six long years.

Anaïs wrote a letter she did not send. It was addressed to the ball. In it she apologized for the fuss and thanked it for being patient and told it that when she retired she would steal it and take it somewhere with no glass and put it on a table and let children touch it until it no longer mattered what anyone had agreed to tell about it. Then she tore up the letter, because dramatics are like silk—they snag on things and then you are beholden to the snag. She instead wrote a note to a girl who had looked at the crack like a scholar and told her she could have a key to the gallery on mornings when no one else was there if she promised not to be precious about her access. The girl returned with a thank-you written on the back of a grocery list, and this delighted Anaïs enough to carry her through three arguments about stairs needing to be painted.

There is a season in every city when the weather decides to be gentle while people are trying very hard to be serious, and it makes everyone’s principles look like hats in the wrong wind. They tried anyway. The Glass Choir held forums that framed kindness as a conspiracy and filled their audiences with the sorts of men who enjoy the posture of shame on other people. Mira spoke less and made her face a place where questions went to die. Lila learned a new way to say “move” with her knees. The locksmith trained an apprentice whose hands were blessedly impatient. Ezra’s wife told him she would not host any more rope in the living room unless it started paying rent. Tomas caught himself one morning rehearsing a speech he would never give and put a spoon in his mouth to shut himself up and went to the bridge and did three quiet things that did not need to be accounted for in anyone’s ledger.

Around the same time, the first person vanished using the thread the bus stop man had shown him. It was an ugly leaving, without oranges or notes. It had no accompanying flood to make the courtesy feel like a response. It looked like a coward’s trick until they found out why—an accountant in a building that made its money off a new category called compliance had decided he did not want to be part of a machine that sold people their own habits with surcharges, and he left his ring on a sink and turned the three taps and thought of a ball hitting a wall and then he was someone else’s problem. He did not come to Tomas or Lila or even to Anaïs; he went to the locksmith, because when you are about to do a foolish, brave thing you look for the person who can fix a hinge and you ask them if you’re crazy and they say yes and then they make you a sandwich. The locksmith made him a ring that would fool a door and told him to come back in three days for the better version, and in those three days the Glass Choir declared a crisis and the city pretended to be surprised, and Mira wrote three sentences that closed a window without looking like it had been there, and the accountant slept very well for the first time since he had been given a password to something that mattered.

Tomas and Lila walked once, finally, at an hour when people do not expect men and women to do anything but sleep or sin. They did neither. They walked the long curve of the river that had lately made itself famous, and they told each other five tiny unimportant truths and did not discuss the way they had begun to carry one another’s reflexes. She pointed at a building that used to be a bathhouse and now sold coffee with insufficient apology for charging rent for conversations, and he pointed at a corner where a boy had dropped a ball in a way he would not forget. They did not touch because touching at that hour in that city carries with it a grammar they had not earned and did not want to borrow; they stood at the marker for the flood of twenty years ago and pretended not to do the math for their ages then. When they parted she said, as if it were an inventory item, that she disliked the word brave when applied to men who were doing what ought to have been less interesting. He told her he would consider being boring for a week. They laughed quietly for the sake of the sleeping.

The city turned a corner without announcing it, and the fact that no one noticed was the proof. Children began to incorporate circles into their play without feeling revolutionary. A market vendor stamped a little orange on the receipts of customers who had taught someone younger how to count change, and the stamp became a thing people compared at parties and then forgot. The Book developed a way to anticipate when someone was about to step on someone else’s heel and gently slowed one of them by showing the weather on a screen for half a breath longer than necessary. The ordinance survived with its italics and its dental work, and the choir kept singing and people bought the pins because pins are pretty whether or not they tell lies. The ball stayed in its case and smiled its crack at cameras, and Anaïs began to say the word retirement out loud in a way that felt like the letter R had been properly sharpened. Mira had a jacket altered so she could raise her arms higher without looking like she intended to hug someone, and she wrote in her yellow pad: permit, audit, forgive, repeat, and put three question marks around the third word because she knew the third word would cost her later.

He took the hex key from the windowsill on a Thursday and put it in his pocket without the red box because pockets, not boxes, had always been where men have kept their inheritances. On the way to his mother’s he stopped at the bench where the pigeons were braver than men, and he drew a diagram on the back of a flyer for a market that promised artichokes at a price that made farmers laugh, and he showed it to a girl who had lost a tooth that afternoon and was collecting opinions about whether she looked like a pirate. He told her that the problem with respect is that it feels too much like softness and too little like leverage, and she told him she didn’t know those words yet and he told her good, keep it that way for a while. He felt, for the first time since he had put the ring down in a small room with blinking lights, that there might be a version of a city he would be proud to be old in. Then a text arrived from Ezra that said in seven words what men who cannot afford grammar say when their day has turned: They took the shop. With a smile.

They had come while the locksmith was showing a girl with a braid how to clean the mouth of a lock with a trick that involved patience and an old toothbrush and a respect for mouths. They had brought a paper that had been written by a person who did not know how to carry keys without looking ridiculous. They had asked him questions that were not questions and had smiled each time he answered in a sentence longer than a verdict. They had unplugged his lathe and his little radio with a sigh that told the room it would be better this way. They had found the teapot with the chips and left it because it was a teapot and they were sentimental about households when they were doing things that injured them. They had told him not to leave town in a voice that made clear leaving town would be proof of the wrong thing. They had confiscated his incomplete rings because the law prefers its lies to be finished. They had left the shop looking temporarily larger and used, like a shirt after a dance. The locksmith stood in the doorway with his hands clasped as if at a funeral and told the girl he would finish teaching her to seat a pin in the afternoon somewhere drier.

Tomas went home and looked at the developer mode like a man looks at a gun he has promised not to keep loaded, and he did not press the taps because the room had begun to smell of tragedy and he had vowed, to nobodies and to himself, that he would not be the person who brought tragedy into rooms unless tragedy had already arrived uninvited. He put the hex key on the table like a set of intentions he was not yet ready to say out loud and called Lila with the economy that makes colleagues of people who have twice lied to protect each other in compatible ways. She told him to meet her on a corner where the Book’s eyes liked to blink. He brought two oranges and the paper with the diagram and the old toothbrush because it felt funny to carry a weapon that had once been useless. They stood together and watched the light do that trick it likes at that hour, turning everyone into the sort of person you hope you are in better stories, and she said, with a patience she did not like having to use on her own mouth, that the next thing would be crueler and more boring, and that they would need to be good at both refusing and yawning. He told her he had practiced both his whole life without awards. She touched his sleeve with two fingers, a gesture that could not be misread by any camera, and walked away to file a report that would not be read by anyone who mattered and would be found by someone who would think they had discovered a small proof of decency. The oranges sat briefly in his pocket like two suns, and he decided to count that, for now, as a surplus.
